<article id="post-1588" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 102A: Advanced Grammar and Composition</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 9-10A, VLSB 2062 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Robertson</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21313</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25</em></p>
<p>Este curso está diseñado para facilitarte el desarrollo de las herramientas necesarias para mejorar tu escritura formal y enfrentar con éxito los requisitos académicos y profesionales. Practicarás la lectura crítica de textos escritos y otros formatos; aprenderás a identificar y superar tus debilidades gramaticales, y avanzarás en tu composición analizando tu trabajo escrito y el de tus compañeros. El curso pondrá énfasis en la escritura de investigación (exposición y argumentación), y en los pasos preliminares de la narración y la descripción. Los textos y el material visual de este curso apoyarán el desarrollo de tu pensamiento crítico y te estimularán a establecer conexiones con los contextos históricos y culturales en los que fueron creados. Te ayudarán también a reflexionar sobre tu propia percepción y tus motivaciones para escribir. Para el final del semestre obtendrás una base sólida de estrategias discursivas y comprensión cultural que te permitirán escribir ensayos bien organizados y claramente apoyados por la evidencia que escogiste, expresando tus ideas en forma efectiva en español.</p>
<p>En Español 102A pondrás en práctica los conocimientos adquiridos y los contenidos trabajados en los cursos de lengua y Español 25. Por tal motivo este curso no tiene como objetivo la re-enseñanza de aspectos gramaticales de cursos previos, sino que los reforzará aplicando la gramática a la escritura, discusiones y presentaciones orales.</p>
<p>Todo estudiante que desee tener éxito deberá trabajar <em>constantemente</em> en la revisión de su propia escritura (redacción y gramática), asistir y participar activamente en clase y completar todas las tareas asignadas en el tiempo indicado.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1588 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1598" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 280.1: Literatura Hispanoamericana: Apreciaciones críticas del canon</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				Th 3-6P, BARROWS 129 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Del Valle</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21280</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course provides an overview of canonical literature from Spain and Latin America from the colonial period to the present. It helps students who are preparing to take the second year examination and it’s also a good option for advanced undergraduates who are considering pursuing graduate studies in literature.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1598 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">

				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->

	<div id="main" class="group">

<article id="post-2856" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 135.2: Borges, Budismo y Ciencia Cognitiva</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 10-11A, DWINELLE B-3 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Barili</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 20971</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25</em></p>
<p>En este curso exploraremos el interés de Borges por el Budismo desde su niñez en Argentina y su adolescencia en la Europa de la Primera Guerra Mundial hasta su madurez, pasando por sus famosos cuentos de Ficciones, poemas y ensayos, conferencias y entrevistas a lo largo de su vida, y su libro ¿Qué es el Budismo?. Para comprender más profundamente las multiples manifestaciones de esta influencia en la obra de Borges y su particular manera de interpretar el Budismo, estudiaremos los principios básicos de esta filosofía. Discutiremos también los descubrimientos más recientes de la Ciencia Cognitiva&#8211; y sus conecciones con el Budismo&#8211; para ver cómo Borges anticipa estos descubrimientos con su radical cuestionamiento de categorías fundamentales del pensamiento occidental al explorar nociones del ser, la realidad, la mente, el conocimiento, el tiempo y el espacio, desde perspectivas budistas. Tópicos relacionados a estas perspectivas, que exploraremos en el curso, son “la unidad de todos los seres”, “el entretejer de karmas”, “la vida como sueño”, “la nadería de la personalidad”, “el tiempo circular”, etc. Como Borges mismo señaló refiriéndose al Budismo, ésta es una filosofía y disciplina basada en la práctica personal: “no se trata de comprender (el Budismo); se trata de sentirlo de un modo hondo, de sentirlo en cuerpo y alma”. La Ciencia Cognitiva, por su parte, también insiste en la importancia del conocimiento que es procesado a través del cuerpo: “embodied learning”. Por esta razón, complementaremos nuestras discusiones académicas con “mini labs” de experiencia y aplicación de la principal metodología budista: la meditación. Comenzaremos nuestras clases con prácticas mentales de calmar la mente y enfocar la atención, y exploraremos sus resultados en nuestras indagaciones intelectuales y creativas. Al principio de cada clase, y antes de nuestras exploraciones sobre lo que hemos leido, haremos breves prácticas de enfocar la mente. Este componente es parte integral del curso. Te recomiendo que llegues a tiempo a la clase para no distraer a tus compañeros y beneficiarte plenamente de esta práctica. Una vez que te hayas familiarizado con maneras de acceder a la contemplación y meditación, puedes practicarla en cualquier momento que la necesites o que quieras cultivarla. Recomiendo que explores los resultados que encuentras practicando unos minutos cada día antes de estudiar y de escribir comentarios o ensayos para cualquiera de tus clases.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2856 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1650" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Catalan 102: Readings in Catalan</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 1-2P, TBA | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Redondo Campillos</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 13201</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course has been specially designed for students who have taken Catalan 101, with special regard to graduate students who need Catalan language as a tool for their research. Graduate and undergraduate students with high proficiency in any Romance language and interested in Iberian studies are encouraged to take Catalan 102 too.</p>
<p>Language will be approached through its different skills, and students will develop their reading and audiovisual strategies in order to comprehend more complex materials -especially Catalan literature, films, and music. Catalan culture will have a relevant role in this course.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1650 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-2053" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 131: Small Masterpieces: Art of the Short Story in Latin America</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				TuTh 11A-12:30P, DWINELLE 205 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Dominguez</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 46254</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Spanish 25</em></p>
<p>Discover the great tradition of the short story in modern Latin American literature. A wide range of stories will be available to read, analyze and debate, drawing on modern and contemporary writers. Students will be encouraged to investigate the internal structure of the genre through critical and theoretical essays—many of them written by the authors themselves. Readings will include works by Jorge Luis Borges, Julio Cortázar, Augusto Monterroso, Silvina Ocampo, Elena Garro, Horacio Quiroga, Juan Rulfo and Guillermo Cabrera Infante.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2053 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->
</div><!-- #wrapper -->

var colomatduration = 'fast';
var colomatslideEffect = 'slideFade';
</script><script type='text/javascript' src='http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/wp-content/plugins/jquery-collapse-o-matic/js/collapse.js?ver=1.6.5'></script>
<script type='text/javascript' src='http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/wp-includes/js/wp-embed.min.js?ver=4.7.5'></script>
<!-- get semesters by ID -->




<!-- insert semester name -->

    jQuery('li.curnav a').each(function(){

<script type="text/javascript">
jQuery(document).ready(function(){
    jQuery('li.nextnav a').each(function(){
        votes = jQuery('a',this).html();
        jQuery(this).html('Spring 2018');
    });                         
});
</script>

<article id="post-1656" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 135: Transatlantic Saudade</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 10-11A, DWINELLE 130 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Carvalho Pinheiro</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 19885</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>What is <em>Saudade</em>?</p>
<p><em>Saudade</em> is one of the most time-honored and fascinating cultural notions still present in Portuguese-speaking societies. How then does it manifest in contemporary artistic expressions, including music, literature, film, painting, music, and architecture. The seductive voice of Brazilian musician João Gilberto, the irresistible rhythms of Cape’s Verde gran diva Cesária Évora, the compelling cinematic images of Brazilian director Eduardo Coutinho, the vibrant paintings of Mozambican artist José Pádua, the humor-laced prose of the Portuguese writer Miguel Esteves Cardoso, and the celebrated Portuguese fado singer Mariza are some of the living clues that will guide us to a fuller understanding of <em>Saudade</em>. This course offers students a unique hands-on opportunity to explore <em>Saudade</em> as a multinational phenomenon through which to discover other cultures.</p>
<p>This course will be taught in Portuguese.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1656 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

			</ul>	
		</div>

<article id="post-1542" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 1: Elementary Spanish 1st Semester</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MTWTF, Location Varies | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Refer to the Schedule of Classes</b>						</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 5</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Spanish 1 aims to develop basic communicative language skills to prepare students to take higher-level Spanish courses. In this course, students will gain oral and written language proficiency following a communicative language learning approach. Students will develop understanding and appreciation of the Hispanic culture and learn and practice basic tenses and linguistic structures (daily routine, likes and dislikes, present and future tenses, etc.). Grammar is not taught explicitly in the classroom; instead students are expected to study the material beforehand and practice it in class.  Students will learn Spanish through a variety of activities such as reading, listening, writing, and speaking in contextualized situations that will give them the opportunity to use the language to complete different tasks. Class time is to be used primarily for oral communication and practice, for this reason, the class will be conducted entirely in Spanish.</p>
<p>This course is appropriate for students with no previous Spanish courses or up to 2 years of high school Spanish. <strong><u>Spanish 1 is not open to students that learned or speak Spanish with family</u>.</strong></p>
<p><strong>* This class requires ten outside hours of preparation each week in addition to five weekly in- class hours</strong><strong>. </strong><strong>If you do not have enough time to devote to this class, plan to take it at another time.</strong></p>
<p><strong>EARLY DROP DEADLINE (END OF 2ND WEEK) APPLIES. Attendance is mandatory for the first two weeks of class. Any student who is not there when roll is taken will be dropped from the class. </strong></p>
<p>Refer to the Online Schedule of Classes for available Spanish 1 sections.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1542 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<div id="main" class="group">
			<div class="content group wideness" role="main">
				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
						

					</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1550" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 2: Elementary Spanish 2nd Semester</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MTWTF, Location Varies | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Refer to the Schedule of Classes</b>						</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 5</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Spanish 2 aims to develop language proficiency beyond the level attained in Spanish 1 to prepare students to take higher-level Spanish courses. In this course, students will gain oral and written language proficiency following a communicative language learning approach. Students will learn and practice a variety of verb tenses and linguistic structures (subjunctive, commands, past tenses, etc.) and develop understanding and appreciation of the Hispanic culture. Grammar is not taught explicitly in the classroom; instead, students are expected to study the material beforehand and practice it in class.  Students will learn Spanish through a variety of activities such as reading, listening, writing, and speaking in contextualized situations that will give them the opportunity to use the language to complete different tasks. Class time is to be used primarily for oral communication and practice, for this reason, the class will be conducted entirely in Spanish.</p>
<p>This course is appropriate for students with 3 years of high school Spanish. <strong><u>Spanish 2 is not open to students that learned or speak Spanish with family</u>.</strong></p>
<p><strong>* This class requires ten outside hours of preparation each week in addition to five weekly in- class hours</strong><strong>. </strong><strong>If you do not have enough time to devote to this class, plan to take it at another time.</strong></p>
<p><strong>EARLY DROP DEADLINE (END OF 2ND WEEK) APPLIES. Attendance is mandatory for the first two weeks of class. Any student who is not there when roll is taken will be dropped from the class. </strong></p>
<p>Refer to the Online Schedule of Classes for available Spanish 2 sections.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1550 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-1555" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 3: Intermediate Spanish 3rd Semester</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MTWTF, Location Varies | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Refer to Schedule of Classes</b>						</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 5</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The primary goal of Spanish 3 is the development of written and oral skills beyond the basic level attained in Spanish 2 in order to fully prepare you for the requirements of higher-level Spanish courses. In beginning-intermediate Spanish you will gain and deepen your formal knowledge of grammatical structures and increase your vocabulary, so that you are able to communicate orally and in writing at a more sophisticated and abstract level. In addition, you will increase your ability to understand and read critically by summarizing and analyzing both literary and non-literary prose. Grammar is not taught explicitly in the classroom; instead, students are expected to study the grammar topics beforehand and use them in class discussions and activities.  Students will develop their language proficiency through a variety of activities such as reading, listening, writing, and speaking in contextualized situations that will give them the opportunity to use the language to describe, compare, analyze and summarize, information. Class time is to be used primarily for oral and written communication, for this reason, the class will be conducted entirely in Spanish.</p>
<p>This course is appropriate for students with 4 years of high school Spanish. <strong><u>Spanish 3 is not open to students that learned or speak Spanish with family</u>.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Please note:</strong> <strong>This class requires the outside hours of preparation each week (in addition to the five weekly in-class hours). If you do not anticipate having ten outside hours to devote to this class this semester, plan to take it at another time.</strong></p>
<p>EARLY DROP DEADLINE (END OF 2ND WEEK) APPLIES. Attendance is mandatory for the first two weeks of class. Any student who is not there when roll is taken will be dropped from the class.</p>
<p>Refer to the Online Schedule of Classes for available Spanish 3 sections.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1555 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1538" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 24: Freshman Seminar &#8211; Brazil’s Greatest Hits: Arts, Literatures, Cultures</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				Tu 1-2P, BARROWS 180 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Slater</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 19514</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 1 (P/NP)</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>An Introduction to Brazil &#8211; no Portuguese required. (1 unit; P/NP)</strong></p>
<p>The seminar offers an introduction to Brazil through its arts and literature. It includes a rapid overview of Brazilian history and some of the things that make Brazil different from other countries in Latin America. We will look above all at the twentieth and twenty-first centuries and some of the dramatic changes taking place within Brazil today.</p>
<p>The course includes two Brazilian arts events.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1538 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-2342" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 280.2: Esteticas Latinoamericanas 1950-2017</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				W 3-6P, BARROWS 180 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Brizuela</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 22443</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>En este seminario estudiaremos las producciones estéticas Latinoamericanas (literatura, cine, arte) del período los años 50 y el momento presente dentro del marco de los proyectos e ideales de modernización y progreso por un lado, y la exacerbada precarización por el otro. Aunque, como veremos, la precarización ya era visible y palpable en los años 50 y 60, aquellas décadas estuvieron también llenas de promesas de mejoría (vía el progreso o la revolución) a las que apoyaron grandes sectores de las poblaciones latinoamericanas. El punto extremo de precarización hoy, resultado de décadas de políticas neoliberales y de fallidas propuestas tanto populistas como socialistas, lleva a plantearse la búsqueda de nuevas formas políticas, sociales y estéticas para el presente y para el futuro por venir.  Nos preguntaremos qué lugar y rol cumplió y cumple la estética en estos escenarios, al estudiar las manifestaciones y corrientes más importantes de la época de América Latina.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2342 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-2058" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 112: Survey of Modern Spanish Culture</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 12-1P, BARROWS 175 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Iarocci</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 46255</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25</em></p>
<p>This course is designed to provide students with a broad overview of the cultural history of modern Spain (18<sup>th</sup>-21<sup>st</sup> centuries). We will examine the major political, economic, social and artistic trends (art, architecture, literature and film) that have characterized modern Spanish culture. The course will also serve as an introduction to the discipline of Cultural Studies. By the end of the course, students should have a solid understanding of the history of modern Spanish culture as well as a broad set of critical frameworks for thinking about, discussing and analyzing cultural production Spanish.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2058 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">

				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>

<article id="post-2037" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 128: Regarding the People in Transit: Survey of Brazilian Literature</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 9-10A, BARROWS 54 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Macedo</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 22235</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course will look into the depictions of public transportation in Brazil as a framework to discuss the main aspects of the cultural representation of the people throughout the Twentieth Century. In a survey that includes major literary works, old and recent songs, and visual art, we will focus on questions of race, class, and power at stake among those using different transportation services, from the streetcar to the metro, from the slave ship to the urban bus. Particular attention will be given to the relationship between public transportation and violence, as well as the role of temporary communities in shaping citizenship, prompting riots and realizing human rights. A working knowledge of Portuguese is required.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2037 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

	<div id="main" class="group">

				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">

<article id="post-2859" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 27: Introduction to Portugal, Brazil, and other Portuguese-Speaking Cultures (In English)</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 12-1P, DWINELLE 206 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Carvalho Pinheiro</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 46642</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Experiencing the 60’s: an introduction to the Portuguese-speaking Cultures</strong></p>
<p>This course offers an overview of contemporary Portuguese-Speaking Cultures and Literatures. The time frame covered by the course is from the sixties&#8211;years of rupture and experimentalism in artistic and cultural production—to the present. Students will study the concrete poetry of the Portuguese author Ana Hatherly, the visual (“Concrete”) poems of the Brazilian author Haroldo de Campos, and the drawings of the Swiss-Brazilian artist Maria Schendel. In addition, the course content will include among others the multi-layered music of the Angolan duet Ouro Negro and the political essays of Cape Verdean academic Amílcar Cabral. Themes such as colonization, decolonization, freedom, will be among the larger, decidedly compelling group of subjects on which the course will touch.</p>
<p>The course will be taught in English and all required texts will be available in English.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2859 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->
</div><!-- #wrapper -->

<article id="post-1581" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 100: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 1-2P, BARROWS 110 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Davidson</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21186</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Spanish 25</em></p>
<p>Taught in Spanish, this course serves as an introduction to the formal linguistic analysis of the Spanish language. It surveys key areas of the field of Spanish Linguistics, including Phonology and Phonetics, Morphology, and Syntax. Additional topics (Historical Linguistics, Semantics, Psycholinguistics, Dialectology, Bilingualism, etc.) in the context of the Spanish language may also be covered. Emphasizing the goals and methodology of the language sciences, Spanish 100 is the foundational course for Spanish department majors in Hispanic Languages, Linguistics, and Bilingualism, as well as for any student interested in the Spanish language and Linguistics.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1581 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-1680" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 135.3: Casa Tomada: Literatura, Arquitectura, Poder</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 2-3P, VLSB 2038 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: McEnaney</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 22226</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>From the claustrophobic spaces of Cortázar’s private rooms or Matías Celedón’s workplaces to the ruins and underground worlds of Antonio José Ponte, the labyrinths and mirrored mansions of Borges, the brutalist monuments of Maples Arce, the city streets of Norah Lange, or the prefabricated constructions of Fabián Casas, Latin American authors have often turned to architecture in their novels, poems, or stories to reimagine the material world and transform the look, sound and shape of literature itself. In this course we will talk about writers and buildings in Argentina, Chile, Cuba, and Mexico during periods of political and artistic revolution, and discuss how their written work engages architecture to think about questions of popular power, housing equality, artistic design, acoustics, and urbanism. We will also look at films, photographs, and paintings to question the limits of literature and ask how different technologies of representation and production—including 3D printing—might help us remake our own constructed world.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1680 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-1597" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 135.1: From Slavery to Citizenship: Literature, Race and Nation in the Hispanic Caribbean</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				TuTh 12:30-2P, DWINELLE 87 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Dominguez</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 20970</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisite: Spanish 25</em></p>
<p>This course is dedicated to studying the links between literature, culture, and slavery in the Hispanic Caribbean. Among the salient themes are the impact of the Haitian Revolution on slaveholding Caribbean societies; the rise and decline of the plantation as an economic model; differences and similarities between systems of slavery in the English, French, and Spanish Caribbean; race and identity in the Caribbean; conspiracies, rebellions, and national projects; and slavery and the literary canon (romanticism, realism, and costumbrismo). Methodologically, the seminar is interdisciplinary: we will work with materials drawn not only from the literature and intellectual history of slavery in the Hispanic Caribbean, but also from visual culture, including lithographs, photographs, and film, and from the medical and scientific archive that took shape around this subject.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1597 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>

				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>

			<div class="content group wideness" role="main">

<article id="post-1653" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 102: Readings in Portuguese</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 11-12P, BARROWS 151 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Donovan</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 18402</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Prerequisites: Portuguese 101, or consent of instructor.</p>
<p>This is an intermediate course for students who have already taken the first level of Portuguese. The main objective of the class is to complement the student&#8217;s knowledge of the basic structure of the language, through a programmatic review, while s/he practices the language by reading, speaking and writing about a series of contemporary texts. Students will practice their ability to speak Portuguese through group discussions of assigned readings and reporting on current events obtained from the internet. Not for native speakers with formal training in Portuguese at high school level or beyond.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1653 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
						

					</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1654" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 103: Advanced Grammar and Composition</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 12-1P, BARROWS 104 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Donovan</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 19796</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>In this course, students will examine and produce a draft and final version of four types of text: <em>crônica brasileira</em>, short story, book (or other work of art) review, and argumentative essay. Each day, students will dedicate ten to fifteen minutes of class time to performing writing exercises that introduce them to new vocabulary, focus on certain grammatical structures and stress differences in tone and register. Also, students will compile a writing portfolio, which, in addition to the daily writing assignments, drafts and final versions of the texts, will include peer editing exercises and reflections on various aspects of the writing process. At the end of the semester, students will practice translating texts from English to Portuguese.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1654 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->
</div><!-- #wrapper -->

<article id="post-1651" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 50: Intensive Portuguese for Spanish-Speakers</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF, Location Varies | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Refer to the Schedule of Classes</b>						</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>An intensive course for students who have no previous study of Portuguese designed to introduce the basics of the language. This offering prepares the student for upper division course work in Portuguese.</p>
<p>Prerequisites: Knowledge equivalent to two college years of Spanish language or consent of instructor.</p>
<p>Refer to the Online Schedule of Classes for available Portuguese 50 sections.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1651 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

			</ul>

	<div id="main" class="group">

<article id="post-1573" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 25: Reading and Analysis of Literary Texts</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF, Location Varies | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Refer to the Schedule of Classes</b>						</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Introduction to literary concepts, terminology, and theory with application to poetic, dramatic, and prose texts.</p>
<p>Enroll in Spanish 25 if you have received a 5 on the AP Spanish language exam. This course has a prerequisite of Spanish 4 or Spanish 22. It is required for anyone wishing to major or minor in Spanish, including heritage speakers.</p>
<p>Refer to the Online Schedule of Classes for available Spanish 25 sections.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1573 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

			</ul>	
		</div>

<article id="post-1579" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish R 1A: Reading and Composition Through Readings of the Spanish-Speaking World</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 9-10A, VLSB 2066 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Briggs</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21334</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course satisfies the Reading &amp; Composition requirement.</p>
<p><span class="descshow overflow">The course will offer students an introduction to the literature and culture of Spanish-speaking worlds, will help them develop their skills as readers and critical thinkers and make significant progress in their ability to write coherent, intellectually forceful expository prose. We will focus on analytical writing by developing control of argument and style. Essays will be produced through a process</span><span class="deschide"> of workshop and revision, with in-class writing, homework, and peer commentary. Our guide will be Style: Lessons in Clarity and Grace. Students meet together and also individually with the professor.</span></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1579 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

					</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-2363" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 164: Spanish Dialectology and Sociolinguistic Variation</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MW 5-6:30P, BARROWS 136 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Davidson</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21841</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25 and Span 100 &#8211; Linguistics Majors can petition to waive these</em></p>
<p>Taught in Spanish, this course serves to further familiarize students with the fields of Spanish Dialectology and Sociolinguistics. The course centers on the empirical study of linguistic variation that characterizes and is inherent to all human languages, as well as the dynamics of language use that give rise to distinct dialects and language change. Course readings include case studies in Sociolinguistics and Language Variation and Change, and constitute the basis for practical instruction in empirical methodologies for sociolinguistics and dialectology research. Students will be encouraged to critically examine traditional prescriptive approaches to Spanish Dialectology.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-2363 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->
</div><!-- #wrapper -->

var colomatduration = 'fast';
var colomatslideEffect = 'slideFade';

					</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1571" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 21: Spanish for Heritage/Native Speakers, First Course</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 10-11A, BARROWS 151 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: TBA</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21081</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Spanish 21 is the first course of an intermediate Spanish Language course for students who speak Spanish in informal settings. This course is designed for first or second generation Spanish speakers in the U.S. who need to develop academic language skills. This course aims to develop formal language through readings, writing and discussion of academic texts and film. Students in this course will become aware of the grammatical differences of Spanish and English and will learn a variety of oral and written registers.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1571 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>

<article id="post-1572" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 22: Spanish for Heritage/Native Speakers, Second Course</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				MWF 10-11A, BARROWS 587 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: TBA</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 20867</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Spanish 22 is the second course of an intermediate Spanish Language course for students who speak Spanish in informal settings, have sophisticated vocabulary and master different grammatical structures. This course aims to continue the development and expansion of academic registers through readings, writing and discussion of academic texts and film. In Spanish 22 students read academic articles, more complex than those read in Spanish 21. Students in this course will develop more sophisticated vocabulary and learn a variety of oral and written registers.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1572 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

			</ul>

	<div id="main" class="group">
			<div class="content group wideness" role="main">

								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">

<article id="post-1600" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 161: Spanish Phonetics and Phonology</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				TuTh 2-3:30P, VLSB 2011 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: CALLAHAN</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21403</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25 and Span 100 &#8211; Linguistics Majors can petition to waive these</em></p>
<p>Taught in Spanish, this course serves to further familiarize students with the structure of the Spanish sound system. The course centers on the vocalic and consonantal inventories of various Spanish dialects using both phonological and acoustic phonetic analyses with the goal of preparing students to conduct phonological and phonetic analyses on Spanish varieties, as well as on their own speech. Emphasis will be placed on the skills and techniques particular to sound spectral analysis. Sociophonetic variation (i.e., constant variability in speech production) will also be addressed in the context of empirical research studies.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1600 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">

				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>

<article id="post-1599" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 135W: La Celestina</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				TuTh 9:30-11A, BARROWS 80 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Navarrete</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21423</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This writing-intensive course is for Spanish majors only</strong>.</p>
<p>This is a writing-intensive course focusing on a close reading of the novel La Celestina. For Calisto it was love at first sight when he wandered into Melibea&#8217;s Garden. Or was it lust? At the suggestion of his servant Sempronio, he hires the witch Celestina to help him seduce Melibea. She succeeds, but by the end of the book Sempronio murders Celestina and is himself executed, Calisto is dead and Melibea commits suicide. In our seminar we will read La Celestina, the first modern Spanish novel, and in our weekly meetings discuss its careful dissection of corruption, hypocrisy, and human motivation. In addition we will also read other literary, legal, medical, and historical texts that will help us understand this novel and contemporary ideas about topics such as sentimental love, sexuality and health, prostitution, witchcraft, salvation, corruption, and suicide. Students will write a number of short projects, building up to a longer essay (14-18 pages), and a final exam.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1599 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->
</div><!-- #wrapper -->

<article id="post-1657" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Portuguese 275: Portraits of “Outsiders” &#8211; A Look at a range of Excluded Others in Brazilian Literature and Film</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				Tu 3-6P, BARROWS 180 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Slater</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 19788</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Working knowledge of Portuguese required</em></p>
<p>Meets the Graduate Certificate in Global Urban Humanities elective requirement</p>
<p>This course examines a range of outsiders within Brazilian society—the rural poor versus the urban poor, particular sorts of women in a male context, indigenous peoples, Blacks, LBGT people, and so on. We will keep returning to the strategies that the authors and filmmakers utilize in their portrayal of these varied “others” who are not just inesquecíveis but memoráveis in the sense of incorporating (and thereby stirring up or re-framing) individual and collective memories. We will also reflect together on the ways in which the works transform their matéria bruta (in the sense of raw material and also, at times, of brutal actions) by building upon, or breaking with, older tropes of otherness. The accompanying critical readings raise important questions that provide a larger social and historical context that emphasize the works’ more collective dimensions. “What,” we will keep asking, “do these particular outsiders-within allow or force the author to do that he or she would have trouble doing otherwise?</p>
<p>Some of the authors and filmmakers include Graciliano Ramos, Clarice Lispector, Raduan Nassar, Milton Hatoum, Eduardo Coutinho, Kleber Mendonça Filho, José Padilha, and Ciro Guerra (the last of these a Colombian filmmaker who depicts an area of the Amazon where one finds Brazilians as well as Colombians.)</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1657 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

			</ul>	
		</div>

<article id="post-1589" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 104A: Survey of Colonial Latin American Texts</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				TuTh 12:30-2P, WHEELER 126 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Del Valle</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21293</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25</em></p>
<p>In this course we will study the colonization of the Americas (16th-18th centuries) as a way of considering what this economic and political relationship has meant at various moments on both sides of the Atlantic: for Spain in particular and Europe in general, as well as for those under colonial control. Some of the key themes on which the course will focus are: the criteria of truth in historical writing and science, the development of new forms of subjectivity, the relationships between distinct racial groups, and the impact of these phenomena on the formation of a world order. The majority of readings will come from the Colonial Period, but we will also examine contemporary theories on colonization.</p>
<p>The course has the following, dual learning objectives for students: first, to foster an understanding of what the “encounter” of these two worlds meant in its time and, second, to study the origins of Latin American countries. On the one hand, the material studied is in conversation with other courses in the department (including those on Medieval and Golden Age Spanish Literature and those on Contemporary Latin American Literature) through the engagement with subjects such as nationalism, indigenismo, and Testimonial Literature, among others. On the other hand, the course intends to stimulate interest in the colonial past and also facilitate the analysis and understanding of texts written in a period very distinct from our own.</p>
<p><strong> </strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1589 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

<article id="post-1674" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> Spanish 107A: Survey of Spanish Literature, Medieval to Baroque</h1>

		<p class="section-spacing">
				TuTh 11A-12:30P, WHEELER 104 | 
			
				<b>Instructor: Navarrete</b>				| <span class="ccn">CCN: 21273</span>		</p>


		<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
							</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Prerequisites: Span 25</em></p>
<p>This survey course in Medieval and early modern literature will cover the evolution of narrative, lyric, and dramatic genres from the 13th century to Calderón de la Barca in the 17th, and put them in the context of the social transformations of their time, particularly the complex relationships between Christian Spain and its Jewish and Muslim counterparts. Works and authors to be studied include a Medieval epic, Arabic-derived frame tales, La Celestina, Lazarillo de Tormes, poems from the oral ballad tradition and by the Marqués de Santillana, Garcilaso de la Vega, Fray Luis de Leon, San Juan de la Cruz, Góngora and Quevedo; two short novels by Cervantes and his contemporary María de Zayas, and plays by Calderón and his contemporary Ana Caro. Students will write two short, 3-4 page papers and take two midterms and a final.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1674 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>

<article id="post-43" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Policies and Procedures</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h3>Important Information Regarding the First Two Weeks of Class for:</h3>
<p><strong>&#8211; SPANISH R1A/B, 1, 2, 3, 4, 21, 22, 25   </strong></p>
<p>We have a very high demand for our language classes, and more students want to take Spanish than can be accommodated. Because of this, we&#8217;ve had to impose strict requirements for attendance and enrolling from the wait list.<strong> Please read the following so that you&#8217;re aware of our policies and aren&#8217;t caught off guard as the semester begins.</strong></p>
<p><b>MANDATORY ATTENDANCE FOR THOSE ENROLLED</b></p>
<p><b>(Note: You are not considered enrolled if you are on the wait list.)</b></p>
<p>Attendance is mandatory for the first two weeks of class. Any student who is not there when roll is taken will be dropped from the course.</p>
<p><b>Switching sections:</b> You cannot use your position in a class to swap with another student. The only way to change sections of Spanish is to drop the class you are enrolled in and put yourself at the bottom of the wait list for the class that you want to take. See wait list policies below for procedures to follow once you are on a wait list.</p>
<p><b>Dropping students:</b> We will be taking roll daily in all Spanish classes and will drop those students who do not attend. For each student who is dropped, one will move in from the wait list.</p>
<p><b>WAIT LIST POLICIES (strictly enforced)</b></p>
<p>There is no “crashing” of Spanish courses. The only way to get into a course is through the wait list, so please be sure that you&#8217;ve added yourself through CalCentral. Once on the list, you are added in the order in which you put yourself on the wait list.</p>
<p><b>Attendance at classes while on the wait list:</b> Only the first five people listed on the wait list will be able to sit in on the class, and they are not guaranteed admittance to the class. Everyone else will be turned away. It is your responsibility to check your status daily to see what your position is on the wait list; do not attend class unless you are #1 &#8211; 5.</p>
<p><b>Enrollment cut-off:</b> We will drop students through the second week of class and then cut off all additional enrollments. Therefore, if you&#8217;re not on the official class roster on Friday of the second week of class you will not be allowed to take the class, even if there is space at that time.</p>
<p><b>Don&#8217;t get caught short a class:</b> If you&#8217;re on the wait list, please be sure to have an alternative plan in place, in case you do not get onto the class roster by our enrollment cut-off date.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-43 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-309" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Programs</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>A Welcome Letter from the Graduate Students of the Department of Spanish &amp; Portuguese at UC Berkeley</h2>
<p>Dear Prospective Students,</p>
<p>Welcome to the web site for the Department of Spanish &amp; Portuguese at the University of California, Berkeley! We encourage you to explore the graduate program, which offers a Ph.D. in Hispanic Languages and Literatures and a Ph.D. in Romance Languages and Literatures. Our programs have attracted an international group of students, with approximately 55 active at any given time.</p>
<p>It’s no surprise to us graduate students that UC Berkeley was recently rated by U.S. News and World Report as the best university in the U.S. for graduate study. Our library collections, easily navigated with the latest technology, are among the largest in the country. All of the UC system libraries are linked to one another, making Inter-Library Loans between campuses convenient for all students. In addition, Berkeley students interested in media studies enjoy access to the immense resource of the Pacific Film Archive.</p>
<p>Throughout the campus our faculty members are respected as some of the most talented and involved members of their fields. Those in the Spanish &amp; Portuguese department are actively publishing and eager to bring their cutting-edge expertise and energy to the classroom. The Portuguese program is strong and expanding, while the Spanish program continues to attract new and talented professors. To compliment courses taken within the department, graduate students are encouraged to branch out and establish working relationships with faculty members in other fields, widening the scope of our studies.</p>
<p>The Berkeley community and campus are famous worldwide for dynamic intellectual community and commitment to the development of solid thinkers; we assure you that as a student here, you will find the same qualities in the department of Spanish and Portuguese. The graduate students are very pleased with our department’s combination of professional rigor and social camaraderie. Professors encourage the sharing of ideas between graduate students and are willing to give detailed commentary on term papers and articles-in-progress. We are always welcome during faculty hours for discussing individual research and further developing classroom discussion. In addition to invaluable support from the professors, graduate students depend on one another for continued intellectual growth and feedback. Many students participate in self-generated working groups, often funded by the Townsend Center.</p>
<p>Berkeley, San Francisco and the larger Bay Area offer unequaled literary and political communities with phenomenal access to cultural events, all set within the gorgeous landscape of the San Francisco Bay. We love it here and take great pride in our work and our supportive, professional environment. Our department certainly has a lot to offer; please contact us with any questions you might have.</p>
<p>Suerte,</p>
<p><strong><em>The Graduate Students</em></strong></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-309 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
		<div class="footer-left">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Department of Spanish & Portuguese</li>
				<li>5319 Dwinelle Hall</li>
				<li>University of California, Berkeley</li>
				<li>Berkeley, CA 94720-2590	</li>
			</ul>	
		</div>
		
		<div class="footer-right">
			<ul id="footerul">
				<li>Tel: 510 642 0471 </li>
				<li>Fax: 510 642 6957</li>
				<li><a href="mailto:gspa@berkeley.edu">gspa@berkeley.edu</a></li>	
				<li>&copy; 2017, The Regents of the University of California</li>
			</ul>
		</div>
		
	
			
		</div>
	</footer><!-- #colophon -->

<article id="post-34" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Application Information</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Note:  Applicants are encouraged to clarify any questions concerning the Admissions/GSI application procedures with the Staff Graduate Adviser at <strong><span style="color: #0000ff;">spanga@berkeley.edu</span></strong></p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;</p>
<p>Applicants for admission to the graduate program in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese must submit the <em>Graduate Division’s on-line Graduate Application for Admission and Fellowships</em> on or before the deadline.</p>
<ul>
<li><em>Deadline</em>:  Ph.D. HISPANIC LANGUAGES AND LITERATURES <strong><span style="color: #0000ff;">DECEMBER 15, 2017</span></strong></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><em>Deadline</em>: Ph.D. ROMANCE LANGUAGES AND LITERATURES <strong><span style="color: #ff6600;">DECEMBER 15, 2017</span></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>The department offers two Ph.D. programs, a<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;"><em> <a style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;" title="HLL Ph.D. Info" href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/the-ph-d-hll/">Ph.D. in</a></em></span> <span style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;"><em><a style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;" title="HLL Ph.D. Info" href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/the-ph-d-hll/">Hispanic</a></em></span><span style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;"><em><a style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;" title="HLL Ph.D. Info" href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/the-ph-d-hll/"> Languages and Literatures </a></em></span></span><strong>a</strong>nd a<span style="text-decoration: underline;"> <em><a title="Romance Languages and Literatures" href="http://romancelangs.berkeley.edu/"><span style="color: #ff6600; text-decoration: underline;">Ph.D. in Romance Languages and Literatures</span>, </a>emphasis Spanish</em></span><em>.</em> Students should become thoroughly acquainted with both degree programs (HLL and RLL) and determine which program best reflects their objectives before submitting their application. <b>A Master&#8217;s Degree in a Linguistics field for applicants to HLL Linguistics is <u>highly recommended</u></b>.</p>
<p>Students are responsible for reading and complying with all application guidelines. All supporting documents listed below must be submitted by the December deadline through the <em>University online application</em>. The time available to departments for the review of applications is extremely limited. We cannot guarantee that documents sent separately will be connected to your application in time for review. Please note that late and incomplete applications will not be reviewed. <span style="color: #333333;">Applications are accepted for </span><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #0000ff; text-decoration: underline;">Fall term only.</span></span></strong></p>
<h3>REQUIRED APPLICATION MATERIALS</h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>Graduate Division Admissions Application:</strong> Applicants must complete the Admission application by logging onto the site directly. The on-line application will become available beginning September for the following year’s Fall admission cycle. <span style="color: #ff6600;"><strong><span style="text-align: center;"><a style="color: #ff6600;" title="Graduate Admissions Application" href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/">http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/</a></span></strong></span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Three (3) Letters of Recommendation.</strong> You must obtain three letters of recommendation to support your application. Letters should be written by persons in a position to judge your academic abilities and potential in the field. They must be submitted online through the University online application. <em><em>Recommendation Letters must be uploaded by</em> DECEMBER 22nd at the latest!!<br />
</em></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Transcripts </strong>– All undergraduate and graduate work from each institution attended. This includes foreign institutions, study abroad programs, junior colleges, and certification programs. A bachelor’s degree or recognized equivalent from an accredited institution with a satisfactory scholastic average of a minimum of 3.0 (B) is required. <strong>Upload <em>unofficial</em> transcripts</strong> with the online application for the departmental review. Official transcripts  will be required if admitted.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>GRE scores </strong>are <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em><strong>not</strong> <strong>required</strong> for the Hispanic Languages &amp; Literatures</em> </span>program, but are required for the <a href="http://romancelangs.berkeley.edu/">Romance Languages and Literatures (RLL) Program</a>. Berkeley’s institution code is 4833.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li> <strong>International students</strong> who have never attended an English-speaking university must take the <strong>TOEFL</strong> examination, or equivalent. Note: Students working on a M.A. degree in Spanish/Portuguese from a U.S. institution are required to take the TOEFL as evidence of English proficiency. A minimum score of <strong>90</strong> on the Toefl iBT is required for admission. TOEFL scores must be less than two (2) years old. You must request that Educational Testing Service (ETS) send the score report directly to UC Berkeley, please use the following codes: <span style="color: #333333;">Institution code: 4833.   </span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Writing Sample.</strong> Required for all applicants. Writing samples should be in the form of thesis or research paper on a topic relevant to the fields of Romance and/or Hispanic languages and literature (about 15-20 pages. English, Spanish, and Portuguese are accepted). Writing sample must be uploaded with the online application.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Graduate Student Instructor Application <span style="color: #993300;">(<a style="color: #993300;" href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/graduate-student-instructorships/">GSI</a>)</span>. </strong>Applications for Graduate Student Instructorship for the teaching of Spanish and Portuguese are accepted from applicants newly seeking admission to our graduate program. Candidates must <strong>upload the GSI </strong>application and recording to the main graduate division admissions application.<strong><br />
</strong></li>
</ul>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Statement of Purpose:</strong></span> In your statement please indicate why you wish to pursue graduate studies, your goals, the intellectual field of primary interest and the topic(s) within it that you have worked on in classes, papers or trips abroad. Please explain why the topic is compelling and how you wish to develop it at Berkeley. For more information <strong><span style="color: #ff6600;"><a style="color: #ff6600;" title="Statement of purpose" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/apply/statement-purpose/">click here</a>.</span></strong></p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Personal Statement:</strong></span> Personal statement should give concrete evidence of your promise as a member of the academic community, giving the committee an image of you as a person. This is where you represent your potential to bring to your academic career a critical perspective rooted in a non-traditional educational background, or your understanding of the experiences of groups historically under-represented in higher education and your commitment to increase participation by a diversity population in higher education. For more information <strong><span style="color: #ff6600;"><a style="color: #ff6600;" title="writing the personal statement" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/apply/personal-statement/">click here.</a></span></strong></p>
<p>IMPORTANT: For the purpose of campus-wide fellowship competitions, applicants who submit the statement of purpose and personal history statement in Spanish/Portuguese should also submit an English version of both.</p>
<hr />
<p>ADMISSIONS PROCEDURES AND CRITERIA</p>
<p>The Departmental Committee on Admissions and Fellowships examines and evaluates all applications for admission (including those with requests for fellowships and/or teaching appointments) early in the spring semester of each year. Its recommendations concerning admission and fellowships are made to the Graduate Division by mid-February.</p>
<p>The Department informs all applicants recommended for admission, admission with fellowship, or admission with teaching appointment in early March; formal admission letters from the Graduate Division follow shortly.</p>
<p>Criteria for the selection of applicants for graduate study in the various programs offered by the Department include the following, the first four being of principal importance: closeness of previous academic record to the stated prerequisites for the program of interest, especially in breadth and strength of studies; recommendation letters, with special attention to evaluations of research potential; GPA in the B.A. (and if appropriate, in the M.A.) courses in the appropriate fields, including language proficiency in Spanish, Portuguese or Catalan; statement of purpose, showing evidence of intellectual initiative and commitment; student&#8217;s stated field of emphasis, in light of departmental offerings and fields of faculty specializations.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-34 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">

<li id="menu-item-1509" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1509"><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/the-ph-d-rll/">The Ph.D. (RLL)</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-51" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Degrees Granted (HLL) 1915-1950</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The following table lists chronologically Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese conferred from 1952 to 1980 (** after title indicates that a copy is on file in the Departmental Library, 5125 Dwinelle).</p>
<table border="2" summary="Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese (1915 - 1950)" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th class="sortable">YEAR</th>
<th class="sortable">NAME</th>
<th class="sortable">DISSERTATION TITLE</th>
<th class="sortable">DIRECTOR</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1915</td>
<td>Rose, Robert Selden</td>
<td>Quevedo and El Buscón</td>
<td>Schevill</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1919</td>
<td>Spencer, Forrest Eugene</td>
<td>Luis Vélez de Guevara: A Study in His Life and Dramatic Art</td>
<td>Schevill</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1925</td>
<td>Cornish, Beatrice Quijada</td>
<td>Francisco Navarro Villoslada (6 vols.)</td>
<td>Schevill</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1925</td>
<td>Spaulding, Robert Kilburn</td>
<td>A Study of the History and Syntax of the Progressive Construction in Spanish</td>
<td>Hills</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1927</td>
