<article id="post-52" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Degrees Granted (HLL) 1952-1980</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The following table lists chronologically Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese conferred from 1952 to 1980 (** after title indicates that a copy is on file in the Departmental Library, 5125 Dwinelle).</p>
<table border="2" summary="Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese (1952 - 1980)" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th class="sortable">YEAR</th>
<th class="sortable">NAME</th>
<th class="sortable">DISSERTATION TITLE</th>
<th class="sortable">DIRECTOR</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1952</td>
<td>Ellison, Fred Pittman</td>
<td>The Novel of Brazil&#8217;s Northeast</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1952</td>
<td>García-Girón, Edmundo</td>
<td>The Adjective: A Contribution to the Study of Modernist Poetic Diction</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1952</td>
<td>Ross, Cecilia</td>
<td>Lope de Vega, La hermosa Ester: An Edition with Introduction and Notes</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1952</td>
<td>Seamans, Theodore Eugene</td>
<td>An Author-Theme Index to the Works of Juan Valera</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1953</td>
<td>Estermann, Hannah</td>
<td>Luis Quiñones de Benavente: His Technique of the Interlude</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1953</td>
<td>Keller, Daniel Schneck</td>
<td>Early Modernist Literary Theories in Spanish</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1953</td>
<td>Schade, George Dewey, Jr.</td>
<td>Classical Mythology in the Modernista Poetry of Spanish America</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1954</td>
<td>McCullough, Joe Thompson</td>
<td>The Spanish of Antioquian Oriente (Colombia)</td>
<td>Kany</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1955</td>
<td>Chadwick, John Rouse</td>
<td>Main Currents in the Venezuelan Novel from Romero García to Gallegos</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1955</td>
<td>Markrich, William L.</td>
<td>The Viaje de Turquía: A Study of its Sources, Authorship, and Historical Background</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1956</td>
<td>Arriola, Paul Manuel</td>
<td>The Viaje a Jerusalem: A Contribution to the study of Spanish Travel Literature</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1956</td>
<td>Bary, David Alan</td>
<td>The Poetry of Vicente Huidobro</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1956</td>
<td>Polt, John Herman Richard</td>
<td>Eduardo Mallea and the Contemporary Argentine Novel</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1956</td>
<td>Reynolds, John Joseph</td>
<td>A Study and Critical Edition of Tirso de Molina&#8217;s El condenado por desconfiado</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1956</td>
<td>Rivas, Enrique Manuel de</td>
<td>La obra de Enrique de Mesa</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1956</td>
<td>Very, Francis George</td>
<td>The Corpus Christi Procession in Spain: A Literary and Folkloric Study</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1957</td>
<td>Anderson, Robert Roland</td>
<td>A Study of the Theory of the Novel in Representative Spanish-American Authors</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1957</td>
<td>Gramberg, Eduard Johannes</td>
<td>El humorismo de Leopoldo Alas, &#8220;Clarín&#8221;</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1957</td>
<td>Zeidner, Betty J.</td>
<td>Cervantine Aspects of the Novelistic Art of Benito Pérez Galdós</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1958</td>
<td>Holton, James Stafford</td>
<td>The Evolution of Attitudes Toward the Social Classes in the Chilean Novel</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1960</td>
<td>Allen, Rupert Clyde Jr.</td>
<td>Structure in the Poetry of Antonio Machado</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1960</td>
<td>Otero, Carlos Peregrín</td>
<td>La poesía de Luis Cernuda</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1961</td>
<td>Wing, George Gordon</td>
<td>Octavio Paz: Poetry, Politics, and the Myth of the Mexican</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1961</td>
<td>Campbell, Brenton Kay</td>
<td>The Literary Themes of Ramón Pérez de Ayala</td>
<td>Morby</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1961</td>
<td>Giles, Mary Elizabeth Gottinberg</td>
<td>Descriptive Artistry in the Novels of Emilia Pardo Bazán</td>
<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1961</td>
<td>Schwartz, Rosalind J.</td>
<td>El Cancionero Manuscrito 3168 de la Biblioteca Nacional (siglo XVI)</td>
<td>Rodríguez-Moñino</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1962</td>
<td>Lozada, Alfredo Ruiz</td>
<td>Contribución al estudio crítico de Residencia en la tierra de Pablo Neruda</td>
<td>Shadi</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1962</td>
<td>Scott, Joseph Reid</td>
<td>Relativism: The Key to the Dramatic Art of Jacinto Benavente</td>
<td>Shadi</td>
</tr>

<td>Monguió</td>

<td>Del Piero</td>

<tr>
<td>1964</td>
<td>Ezcurdia, Manuel de</td>

<td>Alegría</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1964</td>
<td>Urbistondo, Vicente</td>

<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>

<td>Shadi</td>

<tr>

<td>Montesinos</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1965</td>
<td>Koldewyn, Phillip Young</td>
<td>Alfonso Reyes as a Critic of Peninsular Spanish Literature</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>

<tr>

<td>Gericke, Philip Otto</td>

<td>Del Piero</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1965</td>
<td>Meinhardt, Warren Lee</td>
<td>The Mexican Indianist Novel: 1910-1960</td>
<td>Torres-Rioseco</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1965</td>
<td>Vranich, Stanko</td>

<td>Monguió</td>
</tr>
<tr>

<td>Shadi</td>
</tr>

<td>Monguió</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1969</td>
<td>Fainberg, Louise Olga</td>
<td>&#8220;Tratado sobre el título de Duque,&#8221; Ms. del siglo XV, inédito, atribuido a Juan de Mena. Edición crítica y estudio lingüístico y literario</td>

</tr>
<tr>

<td>Shadi</td>

<td>Montesinos</td>

<tr>

<article id="post-53" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Degrees Granted (HLL) 1982-1999</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The following table lists chronologically Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese conferred from 1982 to 1999 (** after title indicates that a copy is on file in the Departmental Library, 5125 Dwinelle).</p>
<table border="2" summary="Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese (1982 - 1999)" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th class="sortable">YEAR</th>
<th class="sortable">NAME</th>
<th class="sortable">DISSERTATION TITLE</th>
<th class="sortable">DIRECTOR</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1982</td>
<td>O&#8217;Connor, Dolores Jeanne Walker</td>
<td>Leopoldo Alas and the Spanish Realist Novel, 1876-1890</td>
<td>Polt</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1982</td>
<td>Cortest, Luis</td>
<td>A Critical Edition and Introduction of Fray Alonso de Madrid&#8217;s Arte para servir a Dios</td>
<td>Durand</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1983</td>
<td>Carpenter, Marilyn Jean Sconza</td>
<td>Vertical and horizontal dialogue in the fifteenth-century Spanish cancionero</td>
<td>Walsh</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1983</td>
<td>Scott, Renée Sum</td>
<td>Obra y vida de Javier de Viana: La experiencia vivida de un narrador del novecientos</td>
<td>Durand</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1984</td>
<td>Smith, Victoria Pehl</td>
<td>Pedro de Oña&#8217;s Arauco domado: An Edition based on the Princeps with an Introductory Study (2 vols.)</td>
<td>Durand</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1985</td>
<td>González, Galo F.</td>
<td>José María Arguedas: El cielo y el infierno. Amor y erotismo en su narrativa</td>
<td>Durand</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1985</td>
<td>Herrera, Luis Javier</td>
<td>Estudio comparado de las imágenes geométricas del tiempo en Manuel Altolaguirre y otros poetas de las generaciones del 98 y del 27</td>
<td>Chapman</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1985</td>
<td>Breidenthal, Marianne</td>
<td>The Legend of Hercules in Castilian Literature up to the Seventeenth Century</td>
<td>Chapman</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1986</td>
<td>Hatherly, Anna Maria</td>
<td>A presioza, de Soror Maria do Ceu: edição crítica e comentada do códice 3773 da Biblioteca Nacional de Lisboa</td>
<td>Askins</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1986</td>
<td>Judicini, Joseph V.</td>
<td>Revision in Characterization and Structure in the Plays of Gertrudis Gómez de Avellaneda</td>
<td>Shadi</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1987</td>
<td>Grünfeld, Mihai G.</td>
<td>Oliverio Girondo y la poesía de viaje</td>
<td>Masiello</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1987</td>
<td>Wangensteen, Encarnación Juárez</td>
<td>Italia en la vida y obra de don Francisco de Quevedo: Un estudio introductorio</td>
<td>Askins</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1988</td>
<td>Boyer, Agustín</td>
<td>Estudio descriptivo del Libro de las virtuosas e claras mugeres de don Alvaro de Luna: fuentes, género y ubicación en el debate feminista del siglo XV</td>
<td>Faulhaber</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1989</td>
<td>Mejías-López, William</td>
<td>La Araucana y el Arauco domado: antecedentes de la novela indigenista moderna</td>
<td>Durand</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1989</td>
<td>Fernández-Colmeiro, José-Angel</td>
<td>Historia crítica de la novela policiaca española</td>
<td>Dougherty</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1989</td>
<td>Kelm, Orlando Rene</td>
<td>Temporal Aspects of Speech Rhythm Which Distinguish Mexican Spanish and Brazilian Portuguese</td>
<td>Azevedo / Ohalla</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1989</td>
<td>García Calderón, Myrna</td>
<td>La narrativa puertorriqueña contemporánea ante la cuestión nacional **</td>
<td>Masiello</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1989</td>
<td>Lindenau, Donald</td>
<td>History of the Panamanian Novel **</td>
<td>Kirkpatrick</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Guémann, Steven Allen</td>
<td>Secondary Predication in English and Spanish</td>
<td>Azevedo</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Holloway, Vance R.</td>
<td>La crítica teatral en ABC: 1918-1936</td>
<td>Dougherty</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Ishikawa, Masataka</td>
<td>Factorization in the Grammar and Syntactic Change: A Study in the Categorical Evolution of Clitics in Spanish</td>
<td>Craddock</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Morrás Ruiz-Falcó,María</td>
<td>Edición y estudio de la traducción castellana de De officiis por Alfonso de Cartagena (3 vols.)</td>
<td>Faulhaber</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Detjens, Wilma</td>
<td>Home as Creation: Origins, Place and Geography in the Modern Latin American Novel</td>
<td>Masiello</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Fernández, Roberta</td>
<td>Toward a Contextualization of José Carlos Mariátegui&#8217;s Theories of Cultural and Literary Nationalism</td>
<td>Masiello</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1990</td>
<td>Dávila, Arturo</td>
<td>En busca de la ciudad perdida: México en el siglo XVI (1519-1575) (2 vols.) **</td>
<td>Kirkpatrick</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1991</td>
<td>Krato, Jennifer</td>
<td>Tradición y cambio: los conflictos ilustrados de Mariano José de Larra</td>
<td>Polt</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1991</td>
<td>Gómez-Bravo, Ana María</td>
<td>Repertorio métrico de la poesía cancioneril castellana del siglo XV (6 vols.)</td>
<td>Faulhaber</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1991</td>
<td>Widdison, Kirk Allen</td>
<td>The Phonetic Basis for S-Aspiration in Spanish</td>
<td>Azevedo / Ohalla</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1992</td>
<td>Xaubet, Horacio</td>
<td>Autobiografía y (meta) ficción en tres relatos de Felisberto Hernández</td>
<td>Kirkpatrick</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1992</td>
<td>Maury, Debra</td>
<td>In Praise of the Hero: The Prose Works of Vicente Huidobro</td>
<td>Kirkpatrick</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1992</td>
<td>Nicolopulos, James Robert</td>
<td>Prophecy, Empire and Imitation in the Araucana in Light of the Lusiadas</td>
<td>Bergmann</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1992</td>
<td>Sasaki, Betty Gail</td>
<td>The Artifice of Ethics: Reading Strategies in Seventeenth Century Spanish Poetry</td>
<td>Bergmann</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1992</td>
<td>Arredondo, Isabel</td>
<td>Encuentros entre Latinoamérica y Europa: El Nagualismo en Hombres de maíz</td>
<td>Slater</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1993</td>

<article id="post-54" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Degrees Granted (HLL) 2000-present</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The following table lists chronologically Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese   conferred from 2000 to date (** after title indicates that a copy is on file in the Departmental Library, 5125 Dwinelle).</p>
<p>For degrees granted before 2000, pages are available here:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/degrees-granted-hll-1915-1950/">1915-1950</a></li>
<li><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/degrees-granted-hll-1952/">1952-1980</a></li>
<li><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/degrees-granted-hll-1982-1999/">1982-1999</a></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table border="2" summary="Ph.D. Degrees in Spanish &amp; Portuguese (2000 - present)" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th class="sortable">YEAR</th>
<th class="sortable">NAME</th>
<th class="sortable">DISSERTATION TITLE</th>
<th class="sortable">DIRECTOR</th>
</tr>

<td>2000</td>

<td>Masiello</td>

<article id="post-38" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Financial Aid</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h3>FINANCIAL SUPPORT</h3>
<p>The Graduate Division administers most merit-based financial awards through the Graduate Fellowship Office (318 Sproul Hall, (510) 642-0672). Need-based financial assistance is awarded through the Financial Aid Office (201 Sproul Hall, (510) 642-0485).</p>
<p>Qualified students in certain literatures may also apply for Foreign Language and Area Studies (FLAS) fellowships. Students interested in other award sources are encouraged to read the literature issued by the Fellowship Office of the Graduate Division (318 Sproul Hall), which describes various restricted fellowships and outside grants. Completion of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form is required for all students, except foreigners. It is usually due at the beginning of March.</p>
<h3>Fellowship for New Students:</h3>
<p>Multi-year University-sponsored fellowships are awarded through an annual campus wide competition administered by the Graduate Fellowship Office. Departments select nominees for fellowships from prospective applicants. Applicants are URGED to complete the fellowship application (Part C-D/E) from the online admission application.</p>
<h3>Graduate Student Instructorship:</h3>
<p>Applications for Graduate Student Instructorships for the teaching of Spanish, Portuguese, and Catalan are accepted from applicants newly seeking admission to a graduate program as well as from continuing graduate students. Formal appointment for students new to the University cannot be accomplished, however, until confirmation of admission is received from the Graduate Division.</p>
<p>Applications are reviewed and evaluated by a departmental committee according to the following criteria:</p>
<ul>
<li>the quality of the student&#8217;s academic record;</li>
<li>the quality of the student&#8217;s previous training or abilities with Spanish, Portuguese, or Catalan as languages, as evidenced in part by a submitted tape of a set reading passage; and</li>
<li>the quality of the student&#8217;s previous record (if any) of teaching any of those three languages at the college level, as reflected both in student and supervisory evaluation</li>
</ul>
<h3>Financial Aid</h3>
<p>Graduate students may apply for need-based loans and work-study through the Graduate Financial Aid Office located at 201 Sproul Hall (642-0485).</p>
<p>Under federal guidelines all graduate students are considered independent, so unless they receive other funding which meets the standard student budget, most students are eligible for some type of financial aid.</p>
<p>In order to receive aid, students must also be enrolled and be making satisfactory academic progress toward their degrees.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-38 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

						<div class="menu-graduate-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-graduate-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1501" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor current-page-parent menu-item-1501"><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/">Graduate Programs</a></li>

<article id="post-37" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Funding &#038; Fellowships</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>All students, except foreign students, applying for Fellowships or Financial Aid are <strong><em>REQUIRED</em></strong> to complete the <strong>FAFSA form</strong> (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) available in 201 Sproul Hall.</p>
<p>A variety of fellowships and fee grants are awarded to graduate students throughout the year. Fellowship fund sources fall into three categories: 1.<span style="text-decoration: underline;"> Departmental</span>, 2. <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Graduate Division</span>, and 3. <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Other</span>. It is the student&#8217;s responsibility to identify appropriate sources of support and meet all deadlines. For further information, please refer to the fellowships bulletin-board located outside the Graduate Assistant&#8217;s office (5309 Dwinelle).</p>
<p>1.    <em><span style="text-decoration: underline;">DEPARTMENTAL</span></em></p>
<p>Applications available in the Graduate Office, 5309 Dwinelle</p>
<table border="2" width="95%" align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Departmental Dissertation Year Fellowship</td>
<td>Available: mid-December<br />
Deadline: January 25</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Chancellor&#8217;s Dissertation-Year<br />
UC Dissertation Year<br />
Mentored Research Award</td>
<td>Available: mid-January<br />
Deadline: February 15</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Summer Research Projects</td>
<td>Available: February<br />
Deadline: March 15</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><em><strong>All of the above are processed by the Department.</strong></em></p>
<p>*  Funding for Non-resident Tuition is not available to students beyond the Normative Time period for the program in which they are enrolled, that is 6 years in the Ph. D. program in Romance Languages and Literatures, and 6 years in the Ph.D. in Hispanic and Languages and Literatures program.</p>
<p><strong>International Graduate Students</strong> Advanced to Candidacy have a maximum of <strong>three years</strong> of Non-Resident Tuition Waiver. If they exceed this time, student will have to pay the full Non-Resident Tuition cost on their own.</p>
<hr />
<p><em>CONFERENCE TRAVEL</em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em><br />
</em></span></p>
<p>This support is available to students whose conference papers deal directly with the dissertation. Students must be<strong> Advanced to Candidacy</strong> to be eligible for support. A maximum of $350 per year may be reimbursed for travel, lodging and meals. Request must be approved by the Chair of the department prior to attending the conference. This application must be accompanied by a photocopy of the invitation or acceptance of the paper, and by a letter from the Chair of the dissertation committee confirming that the paper is related to the dissertation.</p>
<p>Deadlines:</p>
<ul>
<li>Fall/Winter travel:    <strong>September 30th.</strong></li>
<li>Students will be notified by October 15th.</li>
</ul>
<p style="text-align: center;">****</p>
<ul>
<li>Spring travel:           <strong> February 1st.</strong></li>
<li>Students will be notified by February 15th.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li>Summer travel:        <strong>30 days</strong> prior to travel</li>
</ul>
<p><span style="color: #ff0000;"><span style="color: #000000;">Click</span> </span> <strong><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Conference-Travel.pdf"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Conference Travel</span> </a></strong>to download the application.</p>
<hr />
<p><em>Summer Research Grant</em></p>
<p>Call for summer research projects will be announced by mid-February. Students can apply for a maximum of $3,000 to fund their summer research. Applications will be judged according to intellectual excellence and achievement in the field. The request should be geared towards academic progress. Grants may be applied to the following categories:</p>
<ul>
<li>Foreign Language Study</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Attending summer courses related to one&#8217;s specialization and/or research projects.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Travel and stipend for Pre-Dissertation or Dissertation Research.</li>
</ul>
<p>Requirements</p>
<ul>
<li>Students with more than one incomplete are not eligible to apply</li>
<li>For students who have received summer funding from the department in a prior year, please attach a report to your application describing your use of the funds (@300 words).</li>
</ul>
<p>Priority will be given to candidates who have not received summer support in the past. Applicants are strongly encouraged to look for other sources of funding (CLAS, IAS, PSP, Townsend, etc.). Special attention will be given to applications seeking matching funds.</p>
<p>DEADLINE:     Submit your request to Verónica López by mid-<strong>March<br />
</strong></p>
<hr />
<p><em>Support for MLA candidates</em></p>
<p>The department will provide support to candidates interviewing at the annual MLA Conference. Total amount reimbursed will be announced by mid-November.</p>
<hr />
<p>2.   <em><span style="text-decoration: underline;">GRADUATE DIVISION FELLOWSHIPS<br />
</span></em></p>
<p>Applications available in the Graduate Fellowships Office, 318 Sproul Hall. For a full listing, click <strong><span style="color: #800000;"><a title="graduate fellowship" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/fellowships/"><span style="color: #800000;">here </span></a> </span></strong></p>
<table border="2" width="95%" align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Foreign Language and Area Studies:</td>
<td>Deadline:<br />
mid-February</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Applications for the following fellowships are available in the Graduate Fellowships Office: <strong>Bancroft Library Study, Phi Beta Kappa Scholarships, Mabelle McLeod Lewis, Ford Foundation Minority Doctoral, Fulbright and Grants for Graduate Study Abroad, Fulbright-Hays Doctoral Dissertation Research Abroad Grants.</strong></p>
<hr />
<p><em><span style="color: #333333;"><span style="color: #333333;">Conference Travel Grant</span></span></em></p>
<p>Awards to allow Ph.D. and Master’s students in academic degree programs to attend professional conferences (professional programs are not eligible). Applicants must be presenting a paper or poster on their research at the conference they are attending.</p>
<hr />
<p><em>Doctoral Completion Fellowship</em></p>
<p>The Doctoral Completion Fellowship (DCF) provides an incentive for students in certain graduate programs, to complete their degree within a reasonable time. This is a new fellowship program available to students in participating graduate programs who enter in Fall 2010 or later. It replaces the Dean’s Normative Time Fellowship (DNTF). Students in qualifying programs admitted in Spring 2010 and before remain in the DNTF program, as described in the <a title="Guide to Graduate Policy" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/policy/degrees-policy/#f31-deans-normative-time-fellowship-dntf-and-doctoral-completion-fellowship-dcf">Guide to Graduate Policy</a>. Doctoral students who <em>advanced to candidacy</em> will be eligible for <em>two</em> semesters of fellowship (stipend and fees).</p>
<p>The fellowship can be used during any semester within the remaining normative time established for the major, plus one more year (can&#8217;t exceed 7 years). They must be registered by university deadlines in the semester(s) they intend to receive this fellowship. For more information, go to the Fellowship office, 318 Sproul Hall.</p>
<hr />
<p>3.   <em><span style="text-decoration: underline;">OTHER SOURCES<br />
</span></em></p>
<table border="2" width="95%" align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Doreen B. Townsend for the Humanities</strong></td>
<td><strong>Available early October, </strong><strong>460 Stephens Hall</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>Extramural fellowships</strong></td>
<td><strong>Consult <em>The Grants Register</em>, and the <em>Annual Register of Grant Support</em> </strong><strong>318 Sproul Hall<br />
</strong><br />
(Awarded by governmental agencies, private foundations, and corporations.)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>Fellowship Index</strong></td>
<td><strong>Located in 318 Sproul Hall</strong>(Lists fellowships sorted by general subject area)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<hr />
<p>•  <em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> FINANCIAL AID<br />
</span></em></p>
<p>Graduate students may apply for need-based loans and work-study through the Graduate Financial Aid Office located at 201 Sproul Hall (642-0485). Under federal guidelines all graduate students are considered independent, so unless they receive other funding which meets the standard student budget, most students are eligible for some type of financial aid. In order to receive aid, students must also be enrolled and be making satisfactory academic progress toward their degrees.</p>
<p>For more information, visit <span style="color: #800000;"><a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/financial/financial_aid.shtml"><span style="color: #800000;"> the office of financial aid.</span></a></span></p>
<h3><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em> </em></span></h3>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-37 -->

<li id="menu-item-1504" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1504"><a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/funding-fellowships/">Funding &#038; Fellowships</a></li>

<article id="post-35" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Student Instructorships</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><strong>Download GSI Application<span style="color: #ff0000;"> (<a style="color: #ff0000;" href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/GSI-APPL.pdf">HERE)</a></span></strong></p>
<p><strong>Graduate Student Instructorship in the Department of Spanish &amp; Portuguese</strong></p>
<p>In the Department a Graduate Student Instructor (a.k.a. Teaching Assistant) is normally assigned to sections of the Department&#8217;s Lower Division language courses, under the supervision of the faculty Director of Lower Division Courses and the Assistant Directors. GSIs are expected to assist with classroom teaching of one section per term (five hours per week), language laboratory duties, and all other duties connected with the proper functioning of the assigned section, as established by the Director of Lower Division Courses. Fulfillment of these duties and responsibilities will require an average of twenty hours per week (17 weeks = 340 hours).</p>
<p>All graduate students seeking an initial appointment in the Department—for any part of the academic year—-are required to attend the Department&#8217;s orientation program and to enroll, during the initial appointment, in the Department&#8217;s methodology course (Spanish 375—-Teaching Spanish in College), both of which are offered <strong>only in the fall</strong> semester of each year. Students who have completed similar courses or programs at another institutions are NOT exempt from these requirements. Students entering a graduate program in mid-year or wishing to begin teaching in the spring semester must make special arrangements for the completion of the requirements with the Director of Lower Division Courses. GSIs are expected to be available for duty the first day of the semester through the time that final grades have been computed and turned in to the supervisor in charge.</p>
<p>Appointments are for one semester or for one year and are self-terminating. Reappointment is contingent upon: a) continued eligibility as per the qualifications stated above; b) satisfactory teaching performance in the Department, as measured by faculty and student evaluations.</p>
<p>Under exceptional circumstances, upon special recommendation by the Department and with the approval of the Graduate Council, a GSI may assist with a section of an Upper Division course.</p>
<p>The Committee on Teaching of the Berkeley Division of the Academic Senate administers an &#8220;Outstanding Graduate Student Instructor Award Program&#8221; for the purpose of recognizing, upon recommendation by their respective departments, the noteworthy contributions of Graduate Student Instructors. Receipt of the award is recognition and evidence of the instructor&#8217;s exemplary performance, based on criteria that involve teaching effectiveness, command of the subject, skills in preparing and teaching classes, ability to motivate students, and contributions to the course, as evaluated by departmental supervisors. Recipients are presented with certificates of distinction at special ceremonies.</p>
<hr />
<p><strong>DEADLINE FOR NEW APPLICANTS</strong><strong>:  DECEMBER 15</strong></p>
<p>Applications for Graduate Student Instructorships for the teaching of Spanish, Portuguese, and Catalan are accepted from applicants newly seeking admission to a graduate program as well as from continuing graduate students. Formal appointment for students new to the University cannot be accomplished, however, until confirmation of admission is received from the Graduate Division.</p>
<p>Applications are reviewed and evaluated by a departmental committee according to the following criteria: 1) the quality of the student&#8217;s academic record; 2) the quality of the student&#8217;s previous training or abilities with Spanish, Portuguese, or Catalan as languages, as evidenced in part by a submitted recording of a set reading passage (see below); and 3) the quality of the student&#8217;s previous record (if any) of teaching any of those three languages at the college level, as reflected both in student and supervisor evaluations.</p>
<p>Applicants are ranked by the same departmental committee recognizing priority, <em>ceteris paribus</em>, of students in the Department (A), followed by students in other Departments with Hispanic field focused programs (B), and students in other fields (C).</p>
<ol>
<li>Students in the department:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>1.1 First-year students with no fellowship support.</li>
<li>1.2 Continuing students with no fellowship support.</li>
<li>1.3 Students who have already taught 4/5 years (in this order), depending on progress toward degree.</li>
<li>1.4 First-year/continuing (in this order) students with fellowship support.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Related field students from other departments. Romance Lang &amp; Lit, Comparative Literatures:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>2.1 Continuing students with no fellowship support.</li>
<li>2.2 Students who have already taught 4/5 years (in this order), depending upon progress toward degree.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Students in other fields:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>3.1 Continuing students with no fellowship support.</li>
<li>3.2 Students who have already taught 4/5 years (in this order), depending upon progress toward degree.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Application Procedure</strong></p>
<p><strong>1) First-time applications:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Students who are seeking admission to a graduate degree program in the Department must provide the following materials in addition to those required for the general applications for admission:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The specific Application for a Graduate Student Instructorship</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Provide an audio recording with the information and reading passage given below.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>English Language Proficiency:<strong> TSE or SPEAK </strong>test is <em><u>required</u> </em>for all Non-Native Speaker of English, except for student completing a B.A. degree in the United States, and for those who have passed the speaking section of the TOEFL iBT with a minimum score of 26 points.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Students who are seeking admission to a graduate degree program in a Department <u>other</u> than Spanish and Portuguese must provide the above items listed in &#8220;A&#8221; and:</li>
<li>Copies of all academic transcripts.</li>
<li>Letters of recommendation from two professors who know the applicant&#8217;s academic work and/or qualifications for the teaching of Spanish, Portuguese, or Catalan.</li>
<li>Continuing Graduate Students at Berkeley applying to the Department for the first time must provide an audio recording with the passage and the materials listed in &#8220;B&#8221;, as well as the general Application for Graduate Student Instructorship.</li>
</ol>
<hr />
<p><strong>Recording</strong></p>
<p>First time applicants may submit individual <strong>recording</strong> for any or all of the three languages taught in the Department. You must <u>include the material for Part I and Part II</u> on each recording.</p>
<p><strong><em>Part I:        Personal Information </em></strong></p>
<p><em>Id</em>entify yourself; speak for 3&#8211;5 minutes in the language in question about yourself, your studies, the places where you have lived, your plans for the future and<em> then</em> record the appropriate passage as given below.</p>
<p><strong><em>Part II:       Reading Passages </em></strong></p>
<p><strong><em>      </em></strong>            Select the appropriate language passage(s).</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Spanish Passage</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Hubo, en época muy remota de ésta en que vivimos, un poderoso rey, amado con extremo de sus vasallos y poseedor de un fertilísimo, dilatado y populoso reino, allá en las regiones de Oriente. Tenía este rey inmensos tesoros y daba fiestas espléndidas. Asistían en su corte las más gentiles damas y los más discretos y valientes caballeros que entonces había en el mundo. Su ejército era numeroso y aguerrido. Sus naves recorrían como en triunfo el océano. Los parques y jardines, donde solía cazar y holgarse, eran maravillosos por su grandeza y frondosidad y por la copia de alimañas y de aves que en ellos se alimentaban y vivían.</p>
<ul>
<li> <strong>Portuguese Passage</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Atirei os pés incertos para o soalho. Mergulhei na algibeira uma escova de dentes; topando nos móveis, procurei as chinelas que embrulhei num número da Nação. Sem reparo, agarrei dentre as malas um caizote com bandas de ferro; e em ponta de botins desci a escada da Titi, encolhido a rasteiro como um cão tinhoso vexado da sua tinha.</p>
<p>Mal transpus o pátio, a Vicência, cumprindo as ordens sanhudas da Titi, bateu-me nas costas com o portao chapeado de ferro &#8212; desprezivelmente e para sempre!</p>
<p>Estava só na rua e na vida! À luz dos frios astros contei na palma o meu dinheiro. Tinha duas libras, dezoito tostões, um duro espanhol e cobres . . . E então descrobri que a caixa, apanhada tontamente entre as malas, era a das relíquias menores. Complicado sarcasmo do destino! Para cobrir meu corpo desabrigado &#8212; nada mais tinha que tabuinhas aplainadas por São José, e cacos de barro do cântaro da Virgem! Meti no bolso o embrulho das chinelas; e, sem voltar os olhos turvos a casa de minha tia, marchei a pé com o caixote às costas, na noite cheia de silêncio e de estrelas, para Baixa, para o Hotel de Pomba de Ouro.</p>
<ul>
<li> <strong>Catalan Passage</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Entre les coses de la nostra època que no lliguen, n&#8217;hi ha dues que entren juntes a la meva vida quotidiana. Una d&#8217;elles és el problema de la incomunicació, i l&#8217;altra les parets primes de les construccions modernes.</p>
<p>La incomunicació — referida al contacte humà—és evident. A la casa on visc fa més de quinze anys, hi ha vint-i-vuit famílies, allò que a l&#8217;antigor en deien focs. De mitjana, fent un capmàs, crec que som uns, vuitanta veïns, que ens veiem i ens saludem sobretot a l&#8217;ascensor, la cabina del qual pot traginar tres-cents quilos. Persones o una impedimenta de pes equivalent. Si es tracta de persones, una plaqueta d&#8217;alumini amb inscripcions adverteix que no poden passar de quatre adults. Si es tracta de maletes o embalums de mena variada, la cosa és més aleatòria i ho han de deixar al cop d&#8217;ull dels usuaris.</p>
<hr />
<p><strong>University Definitions and Restrictions:</strong></p>
<p>A Graduate Student Instructor (GSI) is a trainee student teacher appointed temporarily by an instructional department. Appointment as a Graduate Student Instructor or in combination with any other University employment may not exceed half-time.</p>
<p><strong>Qualifications:</strong></p>
<p>All Graduate Student Instructors must be registered graduate students at the University of California, Berkeley. They must maintain a GPA of 3.1 or higher, carry a minimum load of 8 units; have no more than two &#8220;Incompletes&#8221;, and make continuous and satisfactory progress toward the degree — within the normative time guidelines established for the degree sought.</p>
<p>All first time Graduate Student Instructors who are not native speakers of English must attain a level of English proficiency sufficient to carry out their teaching duties, as shown by acceptable scores in either the Test of Spoken English (TSE) or the Speaking Proficiency English Assessment Kit (SPEAK). Students who have received their B.A., B.S. degree from an institution in the United States are exempted from this requirement, as well as students for those who have passed the speaking section of the TOEFL iBT with a minimum score of 26 points.</p>
<p><strong>Salary:</strong></p>
<p>The current stipend for one academic year is $20,050.50 and will be paid in ten (10) equal installments. One-semester appointments are compensated at 50% of this salary and paid in five (5) equal monthly installments.</p>
<p><strong>Restrictions:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Four Year Limit:</li>
</ol>
<p>Service as a GSI in the UC System (regardless of campus or combination of campuses) is normally restricted to FOUR years. In exceptional/extenuating circumstances, the Graduate Dean will consider an extension of eligibility. An absolute maximum of six (6) years is enforced in any event. Formal request for extension of appointment beyond four (4) years must be made by the appointing department and must be justified by the student&#8217;s graduate advisor or thesis director as well as by the departmental Director of Lower Division Courses. The letters from the graduate advisor/thesis director must: 1) explain the circumstances that may have delayed the student&#8217;s progress; 2) project completion dates for each of the remaining degree requirements (i.e. qualifying examination, filing of dissertation); and 3) emphasize the student&#8217;s scholarly merits. The letter from the Department Director of Lower Division Courses should support the request for an extension in terms of the student&#8217;s value and merits as an instructor and should include a discussion of the student&#8217;s teaching performance, special assignments, achievements, or special recognitions.</p>
<ol>
<li>50% Time Employment Restriction:</li>
</ol>
<p>Graduate Student Instructorships in the Department are defined by the University as 50%-Time employments and imply that no other appointments in the University or elsewhere may be accepted concurrently with such an Instructorship. Rare exceptions to the rule are allowed, but only by approval of the Associate Dean of the Graduate Division and require, if approved, an 8.95% contribution to FICA taxes on the part of the student.</p>
<p>International graduate student instructors are limited to a maximum of 50% appointment per year. No exceptions.</p>
<p>For information on Unions, Bargaining Agreements, and Labor Relations, please visit their web site at: <a href="http://hrweb.berkeley.edu/hrlabor.htm">http://hrweb.berkeley.edu/hrlabor.htm</a></p>
<p><strong>Disability Resolution.</strong></p>
<p>The campus offers many different resources for graduate students with disabilities. The purpose of an academic accommodation is to offer the graduate student an equal opportunity to meet the department‚s academic standards and requirements. The <a href="http://dsp.berkeley.edu/">Disabled Students Program</a> at (510) 642-0518 serves graduate students with disabilities (who complete the process for establishing eligibility) by authorizing academic accommodations. <a href="http://access.berkeley.edu/">Disabled Access Services</a> at (510) 643-6473 or 643-6456 can usually assist with accommodations to extra-curricular events. Most physical access issues are addressed in the <a href="http://acads.chance.berkeley.edu/CAG/">Campus Access Guide</a>. Finally, problems with accommodations may be reported to the campus <a href="http://acads.chance.berkeley.edu/ada.shtml">Disability Resolution Officer</a> at (510) 642-2795.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

		<style type="text/css">
img.wp-smiley,

	display: inline !important;
	border: none !important;

<article id="post-36" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Summer Teaching Appointments</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department appoints temporary staff during the Summer Session for the teaching of Lower Division language courses. Due to the limited number of posts available, applications are accepted <strong><em>only</em></strong> from students enrolled in Berkeley graduate programs.</p>
<p><strong>I. Applications for teaching courses Spanish 4 or 25.</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Applicants for the teaching of courses 4 or 25 must have had at least one semester of teaching experience of these courses in the regular session.</li>
<li>If not appointed for the teaching of either course 4 or 25, applicants will be considered for appointment to courses of the general series (Spanish 1-3, 15, and 20), as allowed by the definitions of the &#8220;Ranking categories&#8221; of that series.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>II. Applications for teaching courses Spanish 1-3, 15, 20.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Requirements:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>At least two years of teaching experience in the Department&#8217;s regular session Lower Division courses.</li>
<li>OR, at least one year of teaching experience in the Department&#8217;s regular session Lower Division courses in conjunction with at least one year of teaching experience of equivalent Lower Division Spanish language courses at another institution.</li>
</ul>
<p>Applicants are ranked within each of the priority categories set forth below by the Department&#8217;s Committee on Admissions and Graduate Student Instructorships, based on evaluation of 1)the quality of the student&#8217;s previous teaching record (as reflected in both student and supervisorial evaluations) and 2) the quality of the student&#8217;s academic record and progress to the degree within normative time at Berkeley.</p>
<p><strong>Ranking categories:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>First time appointments: </strong>Highest ranking goes to first time appointments for students within the department. They are ranked within that category by progress toward the degree.</li>
<li><strong>Second time appointments: </strong>students of the department are ranked by progress toward the degree with special attention given to those students whose first appointment was for less than full time.</li>
<li><strong>Third time appointments: </strong>students of the department are ranked by progress toward the degree with special attention given to those students whose first and second appointments were less than full time.</li>
<li><strong>Fourth level ranking</strong> goes to graduate students in Hispanic subject-focused programs (in order from the Group in Romance Philology, Comparative Literature, and Latin American Studies). Highest ranking goes to first time appointments.</li>
<li><strong>Fifth level ranking</strong> goes to graduate students in other, non-related fields. Highest ranking goes to first time appointments.</li>
</ul>
<p>To the extent of departmental need, potential appointees are recommended by the Chair of the Department to the Director of Summer Session, following concurrence by the Dean of the Graduate Division, in light of the four year norm for graduate student teaching. Teaching posts in the Summer Session, however, are neither counted in calculations of the &#8220;four year norm&#8221; for graduate student teaching nor in those of the general &#8220;six year&#8221; limitation imposed within the University of California system.</p>
<p><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Applications for Summer Teaching Posts</span>:</strong></p>
<p>Applications are available beginning <strong><em>mid November</em></strong>, and closed in <em>early February</em>. Applications delivered following the announced closing date are considered by the Committee late during the spring term under the basic provisions, categories, and ranking guides stated above, for offer, as departmental need allows, on an emergency basis at the opening of the Session and following satisfaction of all approved applications in the normal selection round.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-36 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-32" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">The Ph.D. (HLL)</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2><strong>Ph.D. in Hispanic Languages and Literatures </strong></h2>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites for Admission</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>A B.A. degree with studies in Spanish, Spanish-American, Portuguese, or Luso -Brazilian literatures or Hispanic Linguistics; or another field with demonstrable bearing on Hispanic and/or Luso-Brazilian studies. <b>A Master&#8217;s Degree in a Linguistics field for applicants to HLL Linguistics is <u>highly recommended</u></b>.</li>
<li>Native or near-native proficiency in either Spanish or Portuguese.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Program </strong><strong>Overview</strong></p>
<p>In close consultation with faculty, the student will develop a specialization in one of <strong>three tracks</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>Hispanic and Spanish American literature and culture,</li>
<li>Luso-Brazilian literature and culture,</li>
<li>Hispanic Linguistics (Spanish, Portuguese, and Catalan).</li>
</ul>
<p>Each track will be organized around student areas of interest. Course preparation will lead to the Qualifying Examination, followed by the completion of a dissertation in the field.</p>
<p><strong>Descriptions:</strong></p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>LITERATURE</strong></span><strong> </strong><strong> (</strong><strong>Tracks 1 &amp; 2)<br />
</strong></p>
<p>Upon arrival in Berkeley, students in these two tracks will meet with a designated First-Year Mentor, who will assess their preparation and advise them on appropriate coursework for their first four semesters. Advising after the first year will be done by the Department’s Head Graduate Adviser (HGA) or a designated assistant adviser. Although students during those first four semesters will naturally want to take courses in their main areas of interest and also look to fulfilling requirements for the Ph.D., they are also expected to concentrate on coursework in areas that they have not studied before, in order to prepare themselves for the general examination.</p>
<p>The immediate goal of the new graduate student is the General Examination, scheduled for their <em>fourth</em> semester. This exam is based on a standard reading list of Spanish and Latin American literature that first-year students will receive when they enter the program. The reading list represents literature from all of the traditional sub-fields. A three-person committee appointed by the Chair will conduct the exam. A Pass is required in order to continue in the program. Students who come to Berkeley with an M.A. or otherwise have a strong preparation may petition to take the exam before the fourth semester.</p>
<p>After passing the General Examination, students will submit a Statement of Purpose that reflects greater intellectual maturity after two years of graduate study, as well as possible changes in primary area of interest, greater understanding of research areas, and other changes in a student’s conception of his/her role in the field. The Statement, together with the results of the General Examination and the student’s performance in coursework, will be considered by the faculty of the Department as a whole, who will then vote whether to allow the student to continue in the program.</p>
<p>Students invited to continue in the program will concentrate their coursework on remaining Ph.D. requirements including any Designated Emphases (Film, Gender Studies, Critical Theory, etc.) they may have chosen. Formal advising will continue to be carried out by the HGA or an assistant. In addition, the specialist in the student’s chosen field will increasingly mentor the student.</p>
<p>The Qualifying Examination will normally take place in the student&#8217;s <em>eighth semester</em>, but may be moved forward in instances of adequate preparation. Early in the semester in which students plan to take the Oral Ph.D. Exam (QE), they will write <em>three</em> field statements, with accompanying bibliographies. Each statement will focus on a pressing topic or problematic, a “deep dive” within the student’s intended field of specialization. The intended fields of specialization should generally track the common areas of specialization in the academic job market. After submitting the three field statements and bibliography, the student will take a 2-day written exam based on questions related to them. The field-statements and the written exam will be assessed by the student’s examination committee in order to determine whether or not the student is prepared to proceed to the oral examination. After passing the Qualifying Examination, students will have <em>two</em> years to research and write a dissertation, embodying the results of original research on a subject chosen by the student. The degree should be completed within the program’s normative time of <em>six </em>years.</p>
<p><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">LINGUISTICS</span> </strong> (Track 3)</p>
<p>Initial reception into the program and advising will proceed as in Tracks 1 and 2 above, with advising carried out by a designated Assistant Graduate Adviser for this track.</p>
<p>All second-year Ph.D. students in Hispanic Linguistics will submit a <em>Qualifying Paper</em> spanning at least one sub-field of Spanish linguistics. The paper should be formatted according to the style sheet of a reputable venue of conference proceedings, such as those from the Hispanic Linguistics Symposium (HLS) or the Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages (LSRL). The paper will be evaluated by a committee of no fewer than two professors specializing in Linguistics (one of whom must be from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese), with the aim of determining whether or not the student is ready to continue on to advanced doctoral research in Hispanic Linguistics. After completing the Qualifying Paper, students will submit a Statement of Purpose. This, together with the results of the Qualifying Paper, will be considered by the faculty of the Department as a whole, who will then vote whether to allow the student to continue in the program.</p>
<p>Early in the semester in which they hope to take their Ph.D. Qualifying Examination, students will submit a <em>second Qualifying Paper</em> spanning at least one sub-field of Hispanic linguistics. The topic of the paper (as opposed to the sub-field in linguistics) cannot be the same as the previous Qualifying Paper and must be of a higher caliber. The student should prepare the paper as if planning to submit it to a non-conference venue, professional linguistics journal. After submitting the second Qualifying Paper, the student will then take a 2-day written exam based on two linguistic sub-fields of the student&#8217;s choosing. The student’s examination committee will assess the second Qualifying Paper and the written exams in order to determine whether or not the student is prepared to proceed to the oral portion of the Qualifying Examination. After passing the qualifying examination, students will have <em>two</em> years to research and write a dissertation, embodying the results of original research on a subject chosen by the student. The degree should be completed within the program’s normative time of <em>six </em>years.</p>
<p><strong>Mentoring</strong></p>
<p>All incoming students will be assigned to a First-year Mentor (1 faculty member) responsible for assessing their preparation and helping the incoming students during their transition into the program. Curricular advising in years 2, 3, and 4 will be carried out by the Head Graduate Adviser or designate in consultation with appropriate faculty, according to students’ interests.</p>
<p>Mentoring for advanced students (years 3 and 4) continues to come from faculty likely to be part of the students Ph.D. Qualifying Examination.</p>
<p><strong>General Examination</strong></p>
<p><u>LITERATURE</u> (Tracks 1 &amp; 2)</p>
<p>All second-year students will take a written General Examination. The exam will be based on a reading list of Spanish and Latin American literature (70-80 titles total) that first-year students will receive when they enter the program. It represents literature from all of the traditional sub-fields (Medieval, Early Modern and Modern Spain, Colonial and Modern Latin America). The General Examination will be administered in the 4th semester, so normally in the spring, although students will be able to petition for an accelerated progress and an early exam.</p>
<p>After completing the General Examination, students will submit a Statement of Purpose. The Statement is similar in scope and length to that originally submitted on the student’s Application for Graduate Study, but should reflect greater intellectual maturity after two years of graduate study, as well as changes in primary area of interest, greater understanding of research areas, and other changes in a student’s conception of his/her role in the field. The Statement, together with the results of the General Examination and the student’s performance in coursework, will be considered by the faculty of the Department as a whole, who will then vote whether to allow the student to continue in the program.</p>
<p>The exam will be administered by a standing committee of the Department, so the same committee will evaluate every student. The exam will be scheduled for shortly after <em>Spring Break</em>, allowing a month for grading.  Passing the exam is necessary for an MA, so students who fail it would not receive that degree. Students may repeat the exam once if they fail it.</p>
<p><strong><u>LINGUISTICS</u> (Track 3)</strong></p>
<p>All second-year Ph.D. students in Hispanic Linguistics will submit a <em>1<sup>st</sup> Qualifying Paper</em> spanning at least one sub-field of Spanish linguistics (chosen by each student; for example, Phonology/Phonetics, Morphology, Historical Linguistics, Sociolinguistics, etc.). The paper should be formatted according to the style sheet of a reputable venue of conference proceedings, such as those from the Hispanic Linguistics Symposium (HLS) or the Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages (LSRL), and should be roughly 10-20 pages long. The paper will be evaluated by a committee of no fewer than two professors specializing in Linguistics (one of whom must be from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese), with the aim of determining whether or not the student is ready to continue on to advanced doctoral research in Hispanic Linguistics. The evaluation is a Pass/Fail, and a Pass is required in order to continue in the program. After passing the Qualifying Paper, students will submit a Statement of Purpose as part of the Permission to Continue. The document must be submitted to the Graduate Office for distribution.</p>
<p><strong>Permission to Continue in the Ph.D.</strong></p>
<p>The faculty of the department as a whole will decide if a student should continue in the program, based on performance on the <em>General Examination/1st Qualifying Paper</em>, experience of the student in coursework, and the student’s Statement of Purpose.</p>
<p><strong> </strong><strong>Course Requirements</strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>All courses used to satisfy a requirement or courses taken toward study program, must be taken for a <em>letter grade </em>option only. Passing grade for graduate students is a <strong>B</strong> or better.</p>
<p><strong> </strong><u>LITERATURE</u></p>
<p>A <em>minimum </em>of <strong>twelve</strong> <strong>courses</strong> are required for the Ph.D. This includes <em>eleven courses</em> in the department, and at least one course outside. Up to two Upper-Division courses would be allowed with permission of the graduate adviser. In addition to the 11, students will take courses for Designated Emphases, language study, etc.  Courses numbered 298, 601, 602 would remain as options but do not count towards course requirements.</p>
<p>The following must be included within the 11-course requirement:</p>
<ul>
<li>One Hispanic Linguistics graduate seminar</li>
<li>One graduate seminar in Portuguese</li>
<li>One graduate seminar outside of the historical period of major emphasis in a transatlantic field (Spanish America for those whose major emphasis is peninsular Spanish; peninsular Spanish for those whose major emphasis is Spanish America)</li>
<li>One graduate seminar in literary theory or containing a strong theoretical component</li>
<li>One course in Spanish and/or Portuguese language pedagogy (Spanish 375)</li>
</ul>
<p><u>LINGUISTICS</u></p>
<p>A <em>minimum </em>of <strong>twelve</strong> <strong>courses</strong> are required for the Ph.D. Up to two Upper-Division courses would be allowed with permission of the graduate adviser.</p>
<p>Coursework Requirements for Hispanic Linguistics Track include:</p>
<ul>
<li>One graduate seminar in Hispanic Linguistics in the student’s primary linguistics sub-field</li>
<li>Two graduate seminars in Hispanic Linguistics</li>
<li>One graduate seminar covering the linguistic structure of a language other than Spanish (C201/2 permitted)</li>
<li>One graduate seminar in the Linguistics Department in the student’s primary linguistics sub-field</li>
<li>One course on quantitative methods for social sciences OR 1 graduate seminar covering linguistic theory</li>
<li>Three additional courses in linguistics</li>
<li>One course in Spanish language pedagogy (Spanish 375)</li>
<li>One graduate seminar in Hispanic or Lusophone Literature</li>
<li>One course related to field of interest, approved by adviser</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Foreign Language Requirement</strong></p>
<p>For students in Literature two foreign languages pertinent to the specialization. Of these, Spanish for students of Luso-Brazilian studies and Portuguese for students of Hispanic literatures are required, and must be fulfilled through graduate course work taught in the pertinent language (not English). The second language requirement must be satisfied by passing the Language Reading Examinations administered by the respective language department. The requirement should be satisfied as early as possible in the student&#8217;s doctoral career and must be completed prior to Admission to the Qualifying Examination.</p>
<p>For students in Linguistics two languages other than the primary concentration are required.   A graduate course in the language or the language reading examination will satisfy the requirement in the Linguistics program. The requirement should be satisfied as early as possible in the student&#8217;s doctoral career and must be completed prior to Admission to the Qualifying Examination.</p>
<p><strong> </strong><strong>Qualifying Examination (QE)<br />
</strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>The examination committee (constituted the semester prior to QE) is made up of <em>five </em>members, including at least one person from outside the Department. One member of the committee will chair the exam; this person may not direct the dissertation<strong>. </strong>All members of the committee, including the “outside” member, must be Academic Senate members. All five members of the Qualifying Examination Committee must be present and voting at the oral examination.</p>
<p>Final composition of the Qualifying Examination Committee is approved by the Head Graduate Adviser. Final versions of the field statements and bibliographies will be turned in no later than one-month before the date set for the oral examination.</p>
<p>Student must complete the QE application form with the Graduate Assistant at least <em>four weeks</em> before the exam. Students may not take the Qualifying Examination if they have more than one Incomplete.</p>
<p>The oral portion of the QE will consist of a <em>three-hour</em> examination conducted by a committee of <em>five</em>, one of whom at least must be from outside the Department.</p>
<p><u>LITERATURE</u> (Tracks 1 &amp; 2)</p>
<p>Early in the semester in which they hope to take their oral Ph.D. Exam, students will write <em>three</em> 5- to 8-page statements, with accompanying bibliographies. Each statement will focus on a pressing topic or problematic, a “deep dive” within the student’s intended field of specialization. The student will then take a 2-day written exam based on questions related to the statements and bibliographies. The field-statements and the written exam will be assessed by the student’s exam committee in order to determine whether or not the student is prepared to proceed with to the oral exam.</p>
<p><u>LINGUISTICS</u> (Track 3)</p>
<p>Early in the semester in which they hope to take their Ph.D. Qualifying Exam, students will submit a <em>2<sup>nd</sup> Qualifying Paper</em> spanning at least one sub-field of Hispanic linguistics (chosen by each student, for example, Phonology/Phonetics, Morphology, Historical Linguistics, Sociolinguistics, etc.). The topic of the paper (as opposed to the sub-field in linguistics) cannot be the same as the previous Qualifying Paper submitted for the second year review, and moreover must be of a higher caliber. The student should prepare the paper as if planning to submit it to a non-conference venue, professional linguistics journal (for example, <em>Language Variation and Change, Language, Phonetica, Bilingualism: Language and Cognition, Journal of Language Contact, Journal of Sociolinguistics</em>, etc.). The paper should be formatted according to the style sheet of one of these professional journal venues, and be roughly <em>20-50 pages</em> long. Having submitted this second Qualifying Paper, the student will then take a 2-day written exam based on two linguistic sub-fields of the student&#8217;s choosing. Exam questions will reflect the student&#8217;s proposed reading list for each sub-field. The second Qualifying Paper and the written exams will be assessed by the student&#8217;s committee in order to determine whether or not the student is prepared to proceed to the oral portion of the QE.</p>
<p><strong>Prospectus</strong></p>
<p>Once the Qualifying Examination has been passed and formal <em>Advancement to Candidacy</em> is approved by the Graduate Division, the student will submit a dissertation proposal, with selected bibliography, to the Dissertation Committee before the end of the first semester following the Qualifying Examination. It is expected that the proposal will describe the intended research, provide a basic bibliography and, if possible, set the project within current research in the field (10-15 pages on average). After examining this material, the dissertation committee will meet with the student to discuss the proposal, to set up a timetable, and to give final approval to the dissertation project. A signed copy of the report should be given to the graduate assistant for the student’s file.</p>
<p><strong>Dissertation </strong></p>
<p>Upon constituting the dissertation committee, the student will apply for Advancement to Candidacy. Doctoral students should bear in mind that it is to their advantage to be “Advanced to Candidacy” as soon as possible following completion of the Qualifying Examination, preferably by the end of the semester in which the Qualifying Examination is passed.</p>
<p><strong> </strong>The student will write a doctoral dissertation under the guidance of a director or co-directors and faculty committee (selected by the student and his/her Graduate Advisor and approved by the Graduate Division), embodying the results of original research on a subject chosen by the student in consultation with the dissertation director(s).</p>
<p>Dissertation committees are made up of a minimum of <em>three members</em>, including one person from “outside” the Department, who serves as the Academic Senate Representative. The Chair of the student’s Qualifying Examination Committee cannot direct the dissertation.</p>
<p>After completion of the QE by the 8th semester, students will have two years to research and write a dissertation according to the program&#8217;s normative time of <em>six </em>years.</p>
<p><strong>Dissertation in a Language other than English</strong></p>
<p>Special approval from the Graduate Council is required to submit a dissertation or thesis in a language other than English. A memo from your dissertation director requesting permission to the Dean must be sent to the Graduate Division <u>early in the first semester</u> following the Qualifying Examination. After approval is given, an abstract in English must be included with the dissertation or thesis. Please contact the Graduate Assistant for instructions.</p>
<p><strong>Normal Progress Schedule</strong></p>
<p>&#8220;Normative Time&#8221; (NT) allowance for the program is set at <em>six (6)</em> years. The Normative time to Advancement to Candidacy is <em>four</em> (4) years (time to QE).</p>
<p>Foreign ABD (All But Dissertation) students have a maximum of three-years (after passing QE) of waived Non-Resident Tuition (NRT) to file the dissertation. Any delay in filing will be at the student expense.</p>
<p>SEMESTER                                            REQUIREMENT COMPLETED &#8212; ALL TRACKS</p>
