<article id="post-28" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">The Major</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department of Spanish &amp; Portuguese offers four options for the major. Listed below are the prerequisites and the requirements for each option. If you are undecided about which major option to choose, please meet with the Undergraduate Advisor to discuss which might be best for you.</p>
<ul>
<li>OPTION A:  THE LANGUAGES, LITERATURES &amp; CULTURES OF THE SPANISH-SPEAKING WORLD (SPANISH REQUIRED)</li>
<li>OPTION B:  THE LANGUAGES, LITERATURES &amp; CULTURES OF THE PORTUGUESE-SPEAKING WORLD (PORTUGUESE REQUIRED w/ SPANISH OPTIONAL)</li>
<li>OPTION C:  LATIN AMERICAN LANGUAGES, LITERATURES, AND CULTURES (SPANISH &amp; PORTUGUESE REQUIRED)</li>
<li>OPTION D:  HISPANIC LANGUAGES, LINGUISTICS, AND BILINGUALISM (SPANISH REQUIRED)</li>
</ul>
<p>All courses within the major must be taken for a letter grade, and a major GPA of 2.0 must be maintained.</p>
<p><strong>PREREQUISITES </strong><br />
Options A, C, and D:  Spanish 1, 2, 3, 4 (or their equivalents), and 25<br />
Option B:  Portuguese 50 (formerly Portuguese 101 A/B and 100), and Spanish 25 if student wishes to complete upper-division coursework in Spanish.</p>
<p><strong>OPTION A:  THE LANGUAGES, LITERATURES &amp; CULTURES OF THE SPANISH-SPEAKING WORLD</strong><br />
This track is recommended for students interested in the languages, literatures, and cultures of the Hispanic World on both sides of the Atlantic.</p>
<p>REQUIREMENTS:<br />
▪ Spanish 104A or Spanish 107A<br />
▪ Spanish 104B or Spanish 107B<br />
▪ Spanish 135W<br />
▪ Three elective courses in Spanish or Spanish-American Literature/Culture<br />
▪ Two elective courses in any upper division Spanish, Portuguese, or Catalan topic</p>
<p><strong>OPTION B:  THE LANGUAGES, LITERATURES &amp; CULTURES OF THE PORTUGUESE-SPEAKING WORLD</strong><br />
This track is recommended for students interested in the language, literature, and culture of the Portuguese-speaking world, and may include up to two upper division electives in Spanish.</p>
<p>REQUIREMENTS:<br />
▪ Portuguese 102<br />
▪ Portuguese 103<br />
▪ Portuguese 104<br />
▪ Portuguese 107A or 107B<br />
▪ Four upper division electives: A minimum of two courses on Portuguese/Brazilian topics, and a maximum of two courses on Spanish/Spanish-American Literature/Culture, Hispanic Linguistics, or Advanced Composition</p>
<p><strong>OPTION C:  LATIN AMERICAN LANGUAGES, LITERATURES, AND CULTURES</strong><br />
This track is recommended for students interested in the languages, literatures, and cultures of both Spanish-speaking and Portuguese-speaking Latin America. It requires coursework in both Spanish and Portuguese, which makes possible comparative approaches to the culture, literature, and history of the region.</p>
<p>REQUIREMENTS:<br />
▪ Portuguese 103<br />
▪ Portuguese 104 or 128<br />
▪ Spanish 104A or 104B<br />
▪ Spanish 135W<br />
▪ Two electives in Spanish, Spanish-American, Brazilian, or Portuguese Literature/Culture<br />
▪ Two electives in any upper division Spanish or Portuguese topic</p>
<p><strong>OPTION D:  HISPANIC LANGUAGES, LINGUISTICS, AND BILINGUALISM</strong><br />
This track is recommended for students interested in the linguistic structure of Spanish and/or Portuguese, bilingualism in society, and/or a career in K-12 foreign language teaching, as well as for future graduate students in (Hispanic) Linguistics.</p>
<p>REQUIREMENTS:<br />
▪ Spanish 100<br />
▪ Spanish 161<br />
▪ Spanish 162<br />
▪ Spanish 163<br />
▪ Spanish 164<br />
▪ One elective in Hispanic Linguistics<br />
▪ One elective in Linguistics (upper division from Linguistics or any foreign language department)<br />
▪ One elective in any upper division Spanish, Portuguese, or Catalan topic</p>
<p><strong>DECLARING THE MAJOR</strong></p>
<p>You can receive pre-major advising at any time, from the Undergraduate Advisor (5317 Dwinelle). Declare the major when you have completed Spanish 25, which you must take for a letter grade.</p>
<p><strong>Single Major:</strong> To declare a single major in Spanish &amp; Portuguese, make an appointment with the Undergraduate Advisor at <a title="undergraduate advisor email" href="mailto:spanua@berkeley.edu">spanua@berkeley.edu</a>, or drop in to see her between 9-12 and 1-4, M-F.</p>
<p><strong>Double Major:</strong> To declare a double major, first download a double major packet from the College of Letters &amp; Science website. Make appointments with both major advisors (Undergraduate Advisor at <a title="undergraduate advisor email" href="mailto:spanua@berkeley.edu">spanua@berkeley.edu</a>, and the other advisor). You will need to prepare a four-year plan, get signatures from both departments, and then meet with an L&amp;S College Advisor in 206 Evans Hall.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-28 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-29" class="group post-container entry-content">
		
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">The Minor</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>We offer three minor programs within the department (please see below for details about each option). All courses must be taken for a letter grade, including all prerequisites. 3 of the 5 upper division courses must be taken in residence here at UC Berkeley. No formal declaration of enrollment in the minor program is required.</p>
<h3>Minor in The Languages, Literatures, and Cultures of the Spanish-Speaking World</h3>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Completion of Spanish 1, 2, 3, 4, and 25 (or their equivalents).<br />
<strong>The Minor:</strong> Five upper division courses in Spanish/Spanish-American language, linguistics, literature, or culture, selected from the offerings of the department.</p>
<h3>Minor in Hispanic Languages, Linguistics, and Bilingualism</h3>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Completion of Spanish 1, 2, 3, 4, and 25 (or their equivalents).<br />
<strong>The Minor:</strong> Spanish 100 (Introduction to Spanish Linguistics) and four other upper-division Spanish linguistics classes, from among Spanish 161, 162, 163, 164, 165, 166, and 179.</p>
<h3>Minor in The Languages, Literatures, and Cultures of the Portuguese-Speaking World</h3>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Completion of Portuguese 50 (formerly called Port 101A/B and Port 101).<br />
<strong>The Minor:</strong> Any five upper division courses in Portuguese/Brazilian language, linguistics, literature, or culture, selected from the offerings of the department.</p>
<h3>Procedure for Confirming the Minor</h3>
<p>If you’ve taken all five upper-division courses at UC Berkeley, during your final semester you need to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Download, print, and fill out the <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/advcompletionoflnsminor.pdf">Completion of L&amp;S Minor Form</a> from the L&amp;S website</li>
<li>Bring it to the Undergraduate Advisor, Jenny Cole, in 5317 Dwinelle</li>
</ul>
<p>Do this even if you’re enrolled in a Spanish or Portuguese course at the time. Note: If you’ve taken one or two of the five upper-division courses outside of UC Berkeley, you must obtain written approval from the Undergraduate Advisor and provide a transcript showing the letter grade you received.</p>
<p><strong>FAQs </strong></p>
<p><strong>Q: I’ve taken Spanish in high school or at a community college. Do I still have to start in Spanish 1?</strong></p>
<p>A: No, the requirement is that you take Spanish 1 &#8211; 4 or their equivalents. Please see the <a href="http://spanish-portuguese.berkeley.edu/placement-guidelines/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">placement guidelines</a> to determine your starting level. If you begin at Spanish 3, you need only take Spanish 4 and Spanish 25 before you begin the courses for the minor.</p>
<p><strong>Q: How many courses can I count towards the minor if I study abroad?</strong></p>
<p>A: For the minor, you can count two upper division courses. You must take three of the upper-division courses here at UCB.</p>
<p><strong>Q: Can I take any course abroad that is taught in Spanish or Portuguese to count for the minor?</strong></p>
<p>A: No, they must be equivalent to courses that we would teach within our department.</p>
<p><strong>Q: How do I get my courses approved while I am abroad?</strong></p>
<p>A: Final approval is only given upon your return, but tentative approval can be given via email at <a href="mailto:spanua@berkeley.edu">spanua@berkeley.edu</a>.</p>
<p><strong> </strong><strong>Q: Where will my minor show – on my diploma, on my transcript, on both?</strong></p>
<p>A: The minor will be posted to your transcript, not your diploma.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-29 -->

										</div>

    jQuery('li.curnav a').each(function(){
        votes = jQuery('a',this).html();
        jQuery(this).html('Fall 2017');
    });                         
});
